title: Boris vows maximum pressure Putin heads Poland Estonia
story: Share this articleShare this articleShare this article   'Frightened kids, frightened looks. They want to eat,' Konstantin Maloletka, who runs a small shop, said by telephone. He said the soldiers went into a supermarket and grabbed canned meat, vodka and cigarettes.'They ate right in the store,' he said. 'It looked like they haven't been fed in recent days.'For many, Russia's announcement of a nuclear high alert stirred fears that the West could be drawn into direct conflict with Russia. But a senior U.S. defense official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the United States had yet to see any appreciable change in Russia's nuclear posture.As far-reaching Western sanctions on Russian banks and other institutions took hold, the ruble plummeted, and Russia's Central Bank scrambled to shore it up, as did Putin, signing a decree restricting foreign currency.But that did little to calm Russian fears. In Moscow, people lined up to withdraw cash as the sanctions threatened to drive up prices and reduce the standard of living for millions of ordinary Russians.In yet another blow to Russia's economy, oil giant Shell said it was pulling out of the country because of the invasion. It announced it will withdraw from its joint ventures with state-owned gas company Gazprom and other entities and end its involvement in the Nord Stream 2 pipeline project between Russia and Europe.The economic sanctions, ordered by the U.S. and other allies, were just one contributor to Russia's growing status as a pariah country.Russian airliners are banned from European airspace, Russian media is restricted in some countries, and some high-tech products can no longer be exported to the country. On Monday, in a major blow to a soccer-mad nation, Russian teams were suspended from all international soccer.In other developments:- The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court said he will open an investigation soon into possible war crimes and crimes against humanity in Ukraine.- Cyberattacks hit Ukrainian embassies around the world, and Russian media outlets.- The United States announced it is expelling 12 members of Russia's U.N. mission, accusing them of spying.The U.N. human rights chief said at least 102 civilians have been killed and hundreds wounded - warning that figure is probably a vast undercount - and Ukraine's president said at least 16 children were among the dead.More than a half-million people have fled the country since the invasion, another U.N. official said, many of them going to Poland, Romania and Hungary.Among the refugees in Hungary was Maria Pavlushko, 24, an information technology project manager from a city west of Kyiv. She said her father stayed behind to fight the Russians.'I am proud about him,' she said, adding that many of her friends were planning to fight, too.

title: The Queen returns duties nine days catching Covid
story: Share this article   The nation's longest reigning monarch, who is believed to have been triple vaccinated, recently spent more than three months resting, on doctors' orders.In the autumn she pulled out of attending the Cop26 climate change summit, the Festival of Remembrance and then the Remembrance Sunday Cenotaph service due to a sprained back. She also missed the Church of England's General Synod.The Queen now regularly uses a walking stick and has been pictured looking frailer recently. She remarked during a Windsor Castle audience last month: 'Well, as you can see, I can't move.'Her lights duties as head of state include working from her red boxes, sent to her every day and containing policy papers, Foreign Office telegrams, letters and other State papers which have to be read and, where necessary, approved and signed.

title: Lord lies Half Britons pretend read classic novels impress poll shows
story: Share this article Some 48 per cent of men and 44 per cent of women are willing to lie about having finished the classics – with young people most likely to fib. Of the 2,000 adults surveyed, 35 per cent said they would lie to look more intelligent, 24 per cent to impress a friend and only 11 per cent to woo a date.Yet more than two thirds said they would be tempted to pick up the classics if they were funnier, according to the survey by TV channel Dave and the University of St Andrews.Dave has said it will give the classics a ‘modern comedy makeover’, reinventing Jay Gatsby as an influencer and putting Wuthering Heights’ Heathcliff in therapy.

title: over one third of north s population hold irish passport
story: Observers have suggested the surge in Irish passport applications, against a decline in British, was due to pragmatism among the North’s unionists since the UK withdrew from the EU.  More than a third of Northern Ireland’s population hold an Irish passport, according to latest official figures.While applications plunged amid overseas travel restrictions during pandemic lockdowns, fresh data from the Department of Foreign Affairs shows numbers rebounding.Already this year, 24,643 people were issued with Irish passports in the North through Northern Ireland Passport Express (NIPX), which is available at post offices in the North. This is more than 400 every day. The figures do not include Irish citizens in the North who apply for their passports directly from Dublin.If the trend continues it suggests more than 150,000 Irish passports would be issued in the North by the year end.This would eclipse, dramatically, the 107,937 issued through NIPX in 2019 – the last full-year figure before coronavirus prevented international travel for most.Issued passports during 2019 in the North soared 27 per cent from the previous year (84,855). This continued a pattern of rising Irish passport applications in the region against declining British applications following Brexit. Official figures show there were 110,506 applications from Northern Ireland for a UK passport in 2019. This was down from 119,298 the previous year, in a continuing 15 per cent slide in such applications from people in the North over a five-year period.LockdownDespite the virus grounding most of the world’s aircraft since the outbreak began, 56,709 Irish passports were issued in the North last year, up almost 16 per cent from 48,911 in 2020, when the first pandemic lockdown was imposed in Ireland.Aggregate figures for the decade 2012 to 2022, to date, show 660,427 Irish passports issued in the North, about 35 per cent of the region’s 1.8 million population. Under the Belfast Agreement, Irish and British governments recognise the birthright of all people in Northern Ireland to identify as either Irish, British or both. There is also a right to dual citizenship and people can carry Irish and British passports. Observers have suggested the surge in Irish passport applications, against a decline in British, is down to increasing pragmatism among the North’s unionists since the United Kingdom withdrew from the European Union. An Irish passport allows them to travel freely within the EU. The Democratic Unionist Party’s Sammy Wilson has previously said he gets “quite a lot” of loyalist voters in his constituency who ask him to sign off on their applications for Irish passports. The East Antrim MP said he encourages constituents going on holidays to opt for an Irish passport as it is a quicker process and negates restrictions imposed on British citizens in the EU as a result of Brexit.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: miriam lord miche%C3%A1l and mary lou see eye to eye never a good omen
story: Students from the Royal Irish Academy of Music play the Ukrainian national anthem outside Leinster House. Photograph: Dara Mac DónaillIt took the threat of a third world war for peace to break out between Micheál and Mary Lou, but even a small mercy is welcome in these monstrous times. The last time the Taoiseach and the Sinn Féin leader were in such accord Ireland was staring down the barrel of a pandemic. If catastrophe makes these two see eye to eye, maybe we’re good with the relative mundanity that accompanies their verbal warfare. There was a muted atmosphere in Leinster House afternoon when the Dáil resumed for the week. On one side of the foyer, four flags were arranged in a line on the marble floor, two on either side of a gilt-framed original copy of the Proclamation: the Irish and EU flags, the UN flag and the flag of Ukraine. Later in the afternoon the House was due to hear statements on the Russian invasion of Ukraine, with more than three hours set aside for TDs to register their condemnation of megalomaniac Vladimir Putin and his barbarous military offensive on a neighbouring democratic country.But the chilling events unfolding on the other side of Europe could not be boxed off into one say-everything set-piece after the usual knockabout was done. From the opening round of Leaders’ Questions and on through the Order of Business and Questions to the Taoiseach, deputies could talk of little else. “What we are witnessing is scarcely believable,” said Micheál Martin, echoing what everyone else was feeling. “But it is very real to the people of Ukraine.” When he called Putin “a bully and a thug”, he did so with the full and unreserved backing of TDs from all sides. That same sense of unity and purpose did not make it across to Brussels, where two Irish MEPs voted against the European Parliament’s resolution condemning Russian aggression against Ukraine. Political half-doors Mick Wallace and Clare Daly, perpetually engrossed in a self-indulgent, left-wing ideological binge, seemed to side against reason, decency and humanity. The parliament voted to condemn Russia by 637 votes to 13. By contrast, in Leinster House there was still plenty of room for differences of opinion, but all speakers were well able to recognise what is right from what is wrong and what is good from what is incontrovertibly evil. People were shook. There are issues and questions around how Ireland will deal with the crisis in the weeks and months to come. Mary Lou McDonald, and Catherine Murphy of the Social Democrats, tentatively began to ask them on Tuesday. Questions about the imposition of further sanctions, how the State will look after the influx of refugees, how Russian money sloshing around the coffers in the IFSC can be frozen and how financial loopholes can be stitched shut.Suddenly discourse in Dáil Éireann starts to sound like it’s been taken from the pages of a cold war novel. TDs and the Taoiseach are discussing the presence of Russian agents living among us and it’s deadly serious. How many to expel? How many, if any, diplomats to keep? Russian embassyThis was one of those days when the word “unprecedented” could be bandied about any number of times. What about the staff in the Russian embassy? Catherine Murphy asked the Taoiseach if the Government has “identified spies” among them. He didn’t say. But as for Russian money resting in Dublin, Martin insisted the State would not go easy on the billionaires. “We have no interest, none, zero, in enabling any Russian oligarch or anyone who is part of the sanctions list, either to evade or avoid being fully accountable to that sanctions regime. We have no interest as a country in protecting anybody in that regard. I have to be crystal clear about that.”With the Dáil talking about oligarchs, there was talk in the chamber of trillions, a figure rarely heard when the ordinary finances of our entire nation is discussed. “The Central Bank has advised that total Russian assets held on December 31st, 2021, are estimated at €11.4 billion, or 0.3 per cent of total Irish fund assets of €3.8 trillion”, he said.People may talk about Londongrad across the water, but apparently there is no such place as Dublingrad over here. Although you wouldn’t want to bet the dacha on that, given the strained relationship many Irish financial institutions have had with the truth in recent years.As the day wore on, the time came for the “statements of support for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine”.“February 24th, 2022, is a day that will live in infamy,” said the Minister for Foreign Affairs, borrowing Franklin D Roosevelt’s famous line uttered after the bombing of Pearl Harbour. Simon Coveney opened the session by saying the motion showed the support every political party and every TD had for Ukraine. “This is Putin’s war,” said Minister for Justice Helen McEntee. “It is an act of an autocratic and dangerous bully.”Less filler, more passionThe speeches continued for more than three hours. In Leinster House, TDs often, after demanding more time discuss a burning issue, run out of speakers and steam well before the cut-off point. In this case, confronted by such a gut-wrenching and compelling subject, deputies spoke over and above the allotted time, with much less filler and far more passion. Talk has to be done, but at times, listening to the very concerned and genuinely angry contributions from deputies, that old chestnut of the Skibbereen Eagle newspaper keeping its eye on the tsar came to mind. But talk they must and, to a woman and man, they did, and as they talked a group of orchestral students from the nearby Royal College of Music assembled with their instruments outside the gates on Kildare Street and prepared to pay philharmonic tribute to Ukraine and its besieged people. About 30 students unfolded their collapsible chairs and assembled their music stands and played the Ukrainian national anthem. People stopped to listen, and politicians came out to hear them. The music was beautiful and it was a desperately sad but lovely occasion. A man by the railings waved a Ukrainian flag and sang quietly. Two younger men, also from Ukraine, sang with pride. Their eyes were brimming with tears, but they were not alone. Nobody spoke much because, well, we didn’t want to cry.In English, this is some of what the distraught and heart-broken Ukrainians sang:Ukraine is not yet dead, nor its glory and freedom,Luck will still smile on us brother-Ukrainians.Our enemies will die, as the dew does in the sunshine,and we, too, brothers, we’ll live happily in our land.

title: mp bob seely names amoral british lawyers muzzling media behalf
story: An MP on Tuesday night used parliamentary privilege to name and shame a string of “amoral” British lawyers whom he said had allowed Vladimir Putin’s “henchmen” to intimidate and silence a free press.Bob Seely, the Conservative MP for the Isle of Wight, told the House of Commons that the UK’s legal system had become “corrupted” by kleptocrats, criminals, and oligarchs.He named four lawyers, most of whom were involved in a series of legal claims brought against publisher HarperCollins and journalist Catherine Belton, author of Putin's People: How the KGB Took Back Russia and Then Took on the West.Mr Seely questioned the morality of John Kelly from Harbottle &amp Lewis, Nigel Tait from Carter Ruck, Hugh Tomlinson QC from Matrix and Geraldine Proudler from CMS.“You have got to wonder about the reputations these people are going to end up with in a few years' time,” he said.“Maybe they are really lovely people. But maybe their amorality is really going to begin to bite their reputations in a way that will be uncomfortable.”‘A coalition of the woeful’He added: “How on earth have we allowed this to happen? A free press should be intimidating kleptocrats and criminals. Why have we got to the position in our society, a free society, where we have kleptocrats and criminals and oligarchs intimidating a free media?“We have a coalition, not of the willing but of the woeful. Oligarchs, Putin’s henchmen, teaming up with amoral lawyers.”The various claims made against Belton and the publisher had threatened to make it the most expensive defamation case in British legal history. They were all settled out of court.Mr Kelly from Harbottle &amp Lewis represented Roman Abramovich, who sued for defamation and received an apology over claims that he purchased Chelsea Football Club on Putin’s orders.Mr Tait represented state-controlled oil giant Rosneft. Hugh Tomlinson QC represented Mikhail Fridman, a Russian businessman and Petr Aven, the head of Russian lender Alfa-Bank.Ms Proudler represented Major Pavel Karpov, a retired police officer at Putin's Ministry of the Interior, who sued British businessman Bill Browder for libel over his campaign for justice for whistleblower Sergei Magnitsky, who was murdered in prison in 2009.UK legal system being abused Mr Seely accused legal firms of setting up a “one-stop corruption shop” that offered “a form of legalised intimidation” used to silence their rivals, journalists and authors.He also warned that “an unstructured and unregulated private eye business” was now collecting kompromat on people in the UK.“People have the right to advice and legal representation but they are abusing it very, very badly in our society at the moment,” he added.His comments come after Labour MP Ben Bradshaw said lawyers working on behalf of oligarchs should be named and shamed.More from NewsBritish father posts on social media about travelling to Ukraine to &#39rescue&#39 wife and sonTeenage girl seriously injured in shooting in LiverpoolLondoners still suffering fallout from Tube strike as many lines remain suspendedRussia-Ukraine latest news: Deadly attack as airborne troops land in KharkivThe Kremlin won&#39t admit that it has already lostLatest pictures from Ukraine: Fighting intensifies as Russian column bears down on KyivMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: southend on sea nine things might not know britains newest city
story: The brutal killing of a member of parliament is a strange context for a momentous municipal decision such as turning a large town into a city. In Southend-on-Sea, that is exactly what has happened in the wake of the murder of Southend West MP, Sir David Amess in October 2021. The awarding of city status was a long-term campaign for Amess, and in the chamber of Southend’s Civic Centre today – where Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, presented the letters patent that set in motion the change from town to city – more than one councillor said Amess had “built this city”. In truth, Southend – described as “a mixture of river rawness and sleazy elegance” in Paul Theroux’s The Kingdom By The Sea – belongs to its people, largely migrants from London and much further afield over the past 150 years. After the dawn of the railways in the second half of the 19th century, Southend became the final destination for all Cockneys on a bank holiday Monday – many of our ancestors never made it on the train back home, deciding instead to put down roots and build the place we see today.1. What’s in a name?  Southend is really South End, the old name for the coastal part of what used to be the greater settlement of Prittlewell, the old parish that faded into obscurity as its southern resort boomed. The Prittlewell Prince find – the earliest dated Christian Anglo-Saxon princely burial in the country, likened to the discovery of Tutankhamun's tomb – was chanced upon in 2003 during the widening of the A1159 road, next to the Aldi. 2. Royal ‘irregularities’Southend’s Royal Terrace was merely The Terrace until the visit of Princess Caroline of Wales, who occupied numbers 7, 8 and 9 for three months in 1803. She came to Southend to seek respite from her doomed marriage to the Prince Regent, later George IV. At an inquiry instigated by her husband in 1806, in an attempt to ruin her, it was stated that “irregularities” had occurred at Southend.3. Pier pressureThe 1.33-mile-long Southend Pier was built in 1830 for paddlesteamers to bring trippers to and from this burgeoning Essex town, so they wouldn’t be beached closer to the shoreline at low tide. It was the work of local entrepreneurs, suggests local historian Jim Worsdale, who were “frustrated and annoyed that passing trade was doing exactly that: passing Southend on new-fangled passenger-carrying steamers”. If you turned the pier on its side it would be the tallest building on earth by some distance. Not that you would.4. Cockney days outSouthend was a dreamland for the Cockney escapee. In 1901, the writer Walter Besant described the mass exodus on Whitsun bank holiday in the late Victorian era: “Above all, at Southend he will find all the delights that endear the seaside to him there is the tea with shrimps – countless shrimps, quarts and gallons of shrimps he is among his own kind there is no one to scoff when, to the music of the concertina, he takes out his companion to dance in the road he sings his music hall ditties unchecked he bawls the cry of the day, and it is counted unto him for infinite humour.”5. Most amusingIn the same year, The Kursaal was built by a businessman from Gravesend. One of the world’s first amusement parks, it remained the largest in the south of England for most of the 20th century. In 1908, Princess Dinibolu of Senegal made headlines around the world for entering the park’s beauty contest. I was once told on good authority that a young Helen Mirren worked at the Kursaal, on a ride called the Skid.6. Sarfend snobberyLocal businessmen fretted about Southend’s ‘excursionists’, as lower-class Cockney tourists were known, threatening the tranquility of the better-heeled inhabitants and middle-class ‘visitors’ of Southend. In 1907, one wrote an open letter to his townspeople, suggesting they rebrand as ‘Thamesmouth’. “How many people know Southend? And how many of them are ashamed of the acquaintance?” he wrote, “It has been so long associated as “Sarfend” where the trippers go to eat cockles and shrimps.” 7. Odds and sodsMuch of the land around Southend was used for brickfields to build London. You can see it from the preponderance of ‘odds and sods’ walls around the area, made of burnt and misshapen bricks taken from the kiln. But after Cockneys fell in love with the sea air (or just with the fact they could breathe it without choking) many swapped London renting for ownership of a modest plot on which to build a low-cost bungalow, leading to the densely populated stretch of suburbs from Shoeburyness to Hadleigh. 8. ‘You all support West Ham!’The site of Southend United’s ground, Roots Hall was used as a quarry that fuelled the housing boom, before it was converted into a football stadium. Away fans would chant “You all support West Ham!” at home games, knowing the area’s ided loyalties: you see West Ham pubs, flags and shirts all over Southend, reflecting the fact that so many of its inhabitants are former Eastenders.9. PoptasticPop has been important in Southend since the 1950s, and the rise of The Paramounts (later Procol Harum) in the new coffee bars and basement clubs that boomed around the town. It is ‘the end’ of Billy Bragg’s 1977 opus, A13 Trunk Road To The Sea, that depicts the dual carriageway route for all Londoners to the Shangri-La of this new city. “I wanted to put the A13 on level pegging with Route 66,” he later said. “Growing up in Barking, that was the promised land, in quite a Springsteenish way. Later, when I saw where Springsteen is from, the New Jersey Turnpike, it did look a lot like Essex.”The Invention Of Essex by Tim Burrows will be published by Profile Books in 2023More from NewsLondoners still suffering fallout from Tube strike as many lines remain suspendedRussia-Ukraine latest news: Deadly attack as airborne troops land in KharkivThe Kremlin won&#39t admit that it has already lostLatest pictures from Ukraine: Fighting intensifies as Russian column bears down on KyivUkrainian refugees escape on train with the lights switched off to hide from Russian shellingGovernment has ‘no idea’ how much its net zero plans will cost BritainMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: long week already stonehenge calendar suggests neolithic ancestors
story: If the week already seems to be dragging, spare a thought for your Neolithic ancestors - who had 10 days to get through. A new appraisal of Stonehenge suggests the megalithic monument was a giant solar calendar that measured the turning of the year in 10-day weeks, beginning at the winter solstice.According to Professor Timothy Darvill, the eminent archaeologist, each upright sarsen stone in the main circle represents a single day. The entire group of 30, when complete, form a single month.Within the circle there is a significant fall in stone size every 11 days, suggesting the beginning of the week was also marked out in the monument.The stone circle would have been built to indicate special festival days and celebrations, such as New Year’s Day, on the winter solstice, when the sunset drops down into the centre gap of three stones - or trilithon - in the south-west. An extra five-day “intercalary” month was added in the run-up to New Year’s Day, to bring the total number of days to 365, which is represented by the five trilithons at the monument’s centre, Prof Darvill believes. Four station stones, which sit in a rectangular alignment outside the sarsen circle, would have been used to keep track of when to add a leap year. “Stonehenge was a monument in use for a long time, but when they came to the stone phase in around 2,500BC they built it in the form of a calendar system,” said Prof Davill, of the University of Bournemouth.“The proposed calendar works in a very straightforward way. Each of the 30 stones in the sarsen circle represents a day within a month, itself ided into three weeks each of 10 days.“Time and ceremony are very much intertwined. People have suggested a calendar would have helped farmers, but no farmer needs to be told when to harvest. This was about ceremony and gaining astrological control of the world by knowing what is going to happen, and when the sun is going to start moving. “The winter seems to be what it’s all about, when the sun sets beautifully between the crack in the south-western trilithon. That points to a key moment in the year. The sunrise on the summer solstice is good but it wasn’t the focus of things.”It was generally believed Stonehenge - which today is a major tourist attraction - was some kind of calendar, because it aligns precisely with the summer and winter solstices. But archaeologists were unsure how it worked, with experts at various times suggesting it was aligned on clock stars, lunar festivals or even eclipses. The clue to the latest explanation comes from the dating of the sarsen circle. Recent research has shown that Stonehenge’s sarsens were added during one phase of construction, around 2,500BC. They were sourced from the same area of the Marlborough Downs and subsequently remained in the same formation, indicating they worked as a single unit. Around the same period, similar 10-week calendars were being adopted in Egypt, raising the possibility that the idea was imported from the east. “There is no reason that it couldn’t have been invented in Britain, but it’s interesting that this happens just when a similar calendar is emerging elsewhere,” added Prof Darvill, whose hypothesis is published in the journal Antiquity.“This is a time when solar cults were emerging and we know that people were moving about a lot.” Although no monthly markers have yet been found, Prof Darvill believes they may have been looted or exist hidden in the surrounding landscape.However, other experts are more sceptical about the explanation.Mike Parker-Pearson, professor of British later prehistory at University College London, said: “It’s certainly intriguing but ultimately it fails to convince. The numbers don’t really add up – why should two uprights of a trilithon equal one upright of the sarsen circle to represent one day?”“As for inspiration from ancient Egypt, the evidence just isn’t there.”More from NewsBritish father posts on social media about travelling to Ukraine to &#39rescue&#39 wife and sonTeenage girl seriously injured in shooting in LiverpoolLondoners still suffering fallout from Tube strike as many lines remain suspendedRussia-Ukraine latest news: Deadly attack as airborne troops land in KharkivThe Kremlin won&#39t admit that it has already lostLatest pictures from Ukraine: Fighting intensifies as Russian column bears down on KyivMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: teaching grammar primary school children does not improve writing
story: Teaching primary school children about grammar does not improve their ability to write, new research claims.The study of grammar at a young age is currently a crucial part of England’s national curriculum, but researchers have now discovered it does little to actually help children’s writing skills.And while the study found learning about grammar does provide some benefit to the construction of inidual sentences, it provides little to no benefit to what it calls “narrative writing”.Narrative writing in the study is defined as a series of sentences that are connected and could therefore be anything from a short story to a letter.The study, funded by the Nuffield Foundation and co-authored by researchers from University College London and the University of York, analysed 70 Year 2 teachers in 70 primary schools and 1,736 pupils.The team concluded that there were questions over whether it was in the children’s best interests to have such a large focus on grammar in the curriculum.Dominic Wyse, the study’s lead author and professor of early childhood and primary development at UCL, said: “The lack of impact of grammar teaching on pupils’ narrative writing raises questions about the extensive grammar specifications that are part of England’s national curriculum.“Currently, the content of England’s national curriculum requires children aged six to seven to be taught grammatical terms such as noun phrase, statement, command and tense.“Older primary school children have to learn terms such as subordinate clause, adverbial, modal verb, active and passive.”The study also looked at a more interactive approach to the study of grammar via an online platform called “Englicious” and while there were some “encouraging” results, they again found there was no statistical improvement in children’s writing ability.The children’s writing was tested via a narrative writing test and a sentence generation task.Speaking to The , Professor Wyse said he believed encouraging young children to simply sit down and write for longer periods could be more beneficial than teaching them “what a noun is”.He said: “My personal view is why do you need to be teaching young children what a noun is? Why do they need to know what the definition of a noun is? I just don’t think that is the most important thing to be doing at that age.“There are evidence-based approaches to teaching writing that have already been proven.“A really simple one is to just practise writing more, and by that I mean having opportunities to genuinely sit and write for extended periods.“Schooling can often be lots of exercises and children rarely get to plan and write at length.“They do of course get the opportunity to do that, in history lessons for example. But it would be ironic if, in their English lessons, they are not given the chance to write.”‘Good vocabulary, good imagination’In the 1960s, the focus on grammar was largely dropped from the curriculum and the priority was placed on “English Literature” – the idea being children would pick up the grammar as they went along.In 2014, the current curriculum was introduced by Michael Gove, then secretary of state for education, and a stronger emphasis was once again placed on the learning of grammar.Debra Myhill, Creative Writing director at the University of Exeter, said that in her view, the question of whether learning grammar at a young age was beneficial to writing was far more complex than the study seemed to suggest.She added: “Being a good writer does mean you need to spell accurately and have grammatical sentences but it also means you need good vocabulary, good imagination and you need to understand narrative structure.“No one single intervention can tackle all of those things at once.”In the UCL study’s conclusion, the authors wrote: “Knowledge about language is not entirely synonymous with grammar as currently conceived in England’s national curriculum.“National curriculum policy makers made selections of curriculum content to be covered based on prioritisation of certain kinds of knowledge at the expense of other kinds of knowledge.”The UCL study concluded that the curriculum should focus more on what helps children to develop their writing skills at different points in development, focusing on teaching approaches such as sentence-combining, planning and emphasising the processes of writing.Professor Wyse said that the national curriculum should reflect the evidence on the value of teaching grammar in classrooms. He added: “Until an in-depth review of England’s national curriculum is undertaken children are unlikely to be receiving the optimal evidence-based teaching of writing that they deserve.”‘Writing for enjoyment’Adrian Williams, a trustee for the Queen’s English Society, said that while learning grammar might not make children “better writers” it would ensure they wrote “correctly”.He said: “Let’s consider what we mean by ‘better’.“If we mean ‘more imaginatively, more powerfully, making a greater impact with what they write’, it seems unlikely that the learning of grammar will improve a child’s ability to write better.“Indeed the learning experience might well deter the child from writing for enjoyment at all.“If, by contrast, ‘better’ means ‘correctly’, it seems reasonable to expect that children who have been taught grammar and have learned the lesson will eventually begin to apply what they have been taught.“Then they will have the advantage that the people who read what they write will give their writing more respect.“Or, putting the case the other way round, people who write incorrectly will run the risk that their writing earns the scorn of their readers: potential employers, for example.”More from NewsBritish father posts on social media about travelling to Ukraine to &#39rescue&#39 wife and sonTeenage girl seriously injured in shooting in LiverpoolLondoners still suffering fallout from Tube strike as many lines remain suspendedRussia-Ukraine latest news: Deadly attack as airborne troops land in KharkivThe Kremlin won&#39t admit that it has already lostLatest pictures from Ukraine: Fighting intensifies as Russian column bears down on KyivMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

news politics alarming-tv-advert-shows-how-"Government TV ad aims to tackle violence against womenByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA stirring advertising campaign highlighting sexual harassment towards women has been launched with a promise the government will not stop saying that women have had enough. The -second television ad shows examples of street harassment, coercive control, unwanted touching, workplace harassment, revenge-porn and cyber-flashing that women put up with daily. Ministers hope that it will lead to lasting change in attitudes as impactful government campaigns have some done over the years with smoking, drink, driving and wearing a seatbelt. Home Office minister Rachel Maclean told the Mirror: “The only way to make successful change is to keep repeating our message that violence against women and girls will not be tolerated anymore. We’re working to change attitudes and behaviours within society so people notice the signs.  We will not stop repeating enough is enough. We just have to keep sharing the message until attitudes finally change.” Payzee Mahmod, Child Marriage Survivor and IKWRO Campaigner, said: “I’m behind this strong campaign which importantly shows that everyone has a role to play in taking action to end violence against women and girls and ensuring that every woman and girl gets the support they need.” Some campaigners admitted the TV ad did not express the form of coercion and domestic abuse well enough, but admitted it would be hard to convey within a short timeframe. Although a number of academics were delighted the Government had taken a step in the right direction.Home Secretary Priti Patel said: “For too long, the responsibility of keeping safe has been placed on the shoulders of women and girls.This campaign says enough, and recognises it is on all of us to demand major societal change. Everyone has a stake in this. “Our new campaign shows that everyone can play a role in challenging abuse and making our country a safer place. “By accepting all of the recommendations in the HMICFRS report I commissioned last year, the Government and the police are doubling down to support victims and survivors and punish perpetrators.”  Andrea Simon, Director of the End Violence Against Women Coalition added: “We welcome this campaign to tackle male violence against women and girls. We can’t end this abuse without addressing the unacceptable attitudes and behaviours that minimise and normalise it. “The End Violence Against Women Coalition has called for a public campaign since , and it is clear that this type of campaign must be long-term, properly funded and shaped by specialist organisations including those led by and for Black and minoritised women.” As Ms Maclean spoke in front of the likes of the Home Secretary, campaigner Nimco Ali, Victims Commissioner Dame Vera Baird, Domestic Abuse Commissioner Nicole Jacobs, Siobhan Baillie Tory MP for Stroud, and Shadow Victims Minister Anna McMorrin, MPs voted down plans to make misogyny a hate crime a short walk away in the Commons chamber. The Government has previously insisted the move will provide more harm than help. But Policing Minister Kit Malthouse was slammed in the Commons, accused of “ignoring women”. Labour MP Stella Creasy said during the debate on the controversial police and crime Bill: “If he continues to ignore women,he continues to say that he understands the challenge, to blame them for not coming forward and report things … he’s right to shake and thrash his head, but he can probably go home without looking over his shoulder.Many of us can’t.” A senior official told the Mirror it was quite ironic the Government were launching a campaign to protect violence against women and girls as MPs blocked a bill to make misogyny a hate crime. Earlier this week it was confirmed police would be told to give violence against women and girls the same priority as terrorism and organised crime. Ms Patel is to add the crime to the Strategic Policing Requirement which sets how resources are to be allocated by the  forces in England and Wales.  The Home Secretary’s move follows outrage at the horric murder of Sarah Everard, , abducted and killed almost a year ago by a serving officer as she walked home near London’s Clapham Common. Ms Patel said: “The safety of women and girls is an absolute priority and I do not accept that violence against them is inevitable.” The SPR sets out how Chief Constables and Police and Crime Commissioners should do their jobs and the priorities they must deliver on. Rachel Williams, a domestic abuse survivor was shot by her ex-husband Darren Williams after she asked him for a orce and her son Jack killed himself just six weeks later. She told the audience at the Commons reception: “Sadly through society, we reinforce the blame on the victim. We focus on the victim and not the person who did it, the perpetrator. Why does she keep going back  What was she wearing  Why did these women white women like this  One does she run  Or does she just leave ” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Vera BairdHome OfficeCrimeDomestic violencePolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: british cover up nuclear tests
story: Heres how the British Establishment covers up a scandal, in the most devious way possibleSuccessive governments have hidden the data on cancers and early deaths in survivors of Cold War radiation experiments for decades, says Fleet Street FoxMedia and officials on HMS Alert in May  to witness the Grapple X bomb - they were at a safer distance than most of the servicemen, protected by flash suits and sunglasses while armed forces had little or none. Observers went home afterwards, while the troops lived in the fallout at Christmas Island for up to a year Image: MirrorpixopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb |commentsSeventy years ago this October, Britain detonated its first atomic bomb. The  further nuclear weapon trials ious governments conducted over decades are the reason why, today, Vladimir Putin probably isnapost going to irradiate the UK by teatime. And for the past  years, the servicemen who delivered our nuclear deterrent have been saying they got cancer as a result. That their wives miscarried repeatedly. That children were born with defects - deformities, poor plumbing, extra teeth.To every complaint, each government said the same: there is no evidence. Until Thursday morning, when, just as Putin rolled his tanks into Ukraine, officials published an update to a government study into the health of the nuclear test veterans.  Read the full story of Britainaposs nuclear tests at DAMNED And for the first time it said they were right. They are more likely to die and get cancer. Seven decades after developing a weapon always intended to be physically and genetically devastating to any living thing exposed to it, government scientists admitted that a long-term detrimental health effect associated with participation in the tests cannot be completely ruled out.It took a day to digest the -page report, packed with statistical tables, but the figure which jumped out was that test veterans were . times more likely to die from chronic myeloid leukaemia, a type of bone cancer that, the report says, is radiation-inducible. A further  pages of supplementary material establishes % of the crew of HMS Diana, a warship ordered twice to sail through fallout, had died, almost all from tumours. They show that RAF ground crew who washed down planes that had flown through the mushroom clouds were  times more likely to die from leukaemia. Read moreAnd, perhaps most devastatingly for all those governments which twisted reality and logic to deny these men the truth, suicide rates were excessive in every single decade since the tests began. But something wasnapost right. " target"_self" rel"nofollow"This study began in , with updates in  and . They backed up the government line to such an extent veterans called them a cover-up and whitewash. The new one was ordered in , after the Mirror launched a medal campaign. The authors say the extra  years made it possible to study in more detail and with greater statistical certainty the potential lelong health impact of test participation. Yet on page , the report compares all this extra information with studies from before : reports which do not have that detail. How was it possible, we asked the researchers, to compare, when this is the first time weaposve seen it  We were told that the previous three reports were summary papers, and published alongside them at the same time were companion reports with extra data. Veterans, families, campaigners, lawyers, and war pension advocates were amazed. This was the first time they had been told the first  studies were summaries, and that there was anything extra. We asked when and where these companion reports were published. We were told they all have ISBN numbers, and were available from government agencies. And they were mentioned in the summaries.With the latest study, all  have now been put online. So we had a look at the first, which was only ever available previously in paper format. It was  pages long, and published in the British Medical Journal on January , . Nowhere within it does it state that there is extra detail in a companion report.What there is, is a footnote. It could be identied as the right reference only because it mentions a code also used on the front page of the companion report. This report could be found onlyyou already had it. This footnote is referenced in the paper just twice, and says merely that the companion report describes methodology and verication checks. There is no mention, whatsoever, of it containing DATA . But this extra information is eye-opening. Spread across  pages, it shows test veterans are . times more likely to die from leukaemia, . times more likely to die from bladder cancer, and raised rates of suicide. And thereaposs a table showing  test veterans dead from chronic myeloid leukaemia, compared to none in the control group, a statistically-signicant figure with a low rate of probability, which means men at the nuclear tests were  TIMES more likely to get a radiation-inducible bone cancer than anyone  in the population.A call to the Stationery Office established that not one copy of this companion report had even been published, not once in  years.  It is entirely possible, therefore, that you are one of the first people in the world to ever see what the British state has known for most of your le: that men ordered to take part in experiments weaponising radiation were more likely to die as a result.Despite knowing that, the state fought every war pension claim and court case. It issued denials to every Daily Mirror story. It sent ministers to the Despatch Box to say there was no evidence. It did it all using millions of pounds of taxpayersapos money - your money.Thousands of test veterans have died, uncompensated and unrecognised, because no-one told them about the companion reports. Hundreds of thousands of children have been born to parents who ask a doctor why, and the doctor just shrugs, because this data was hidden in the footnotes. Decades have rolled slowly by while whole families of men who served their country went in and out of hospital, lost jobs, lost faith, and grieved for those who took their own lives. Ministers were briefed by advisers, who read the reportaposs front page which blames smoking and says that, overall there was no detectable effect on health from the tests. Editors and defence reporters in a once-angry media listened to briefings from the MoD, and shrugged the story away. Read more Even veterans and lawyers, who pored over these documents, had no reason to think there was proof within them that radiation-linked bone cancer could be linked to explosions of plutonium isotopes that have been considered toxic and bone-seeking almost since their discovery. Yet here it is, hidden in the open, unpublished but publishable, something that has never existed in physical form and which can be seen only to those whoaposve seen it already. It takes a special level of deviousness to cover something up while at the same time covering your own arse to effectively hide something in a microdot, so that you can always say it was published at the time.It could be argued that the passage of time has made the test veteran data clearer, and the figures worse. As some of these illnesses are more common with age, there is a clearer comparison with the control group. But it is indisputable that at least those  men who died from radiogenic bone cancer within  years of the tests could have had a war pension from the moment they fell ill. Their widows,they were married, could have had a pension too they could have had faith. Instead they were denied even a medal by a state which puts itself above the people it serves.It would have cost us two things: a fraction of the money spent fighting the veterans, and the pride of an Establishment which is simply unable to admit it ever did wrong. Both would have been worth paying, and weaposd have a finer country for it. One which, perhaps, that would never have let a despot who puts radiation in a pot of tea be in a position to invade anywhere. story: MPs to get £, pay rise as Britain braces for soaring energy bills and tax hikesThe .% hike from £, to £, is likely to spark fury as the country braces for a cost of living crisisByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsMPs will get a mammoth £, pay rise from next month, it has been revealed.The Independent Parliamentary Standards Authorityrevealed the annual pay hike for Members of Parliament for - - after it was frozen for two years during the Covid- pandemic.But the .% hike from £, to £, is likely to spark fury as the country braces for a cost of living crisis. MPs’ pay is set by IPSA, the independent watchdog set up in the wake of the MPs’ expenses scandal. The calculation is based on the average change in salaries for public sector workers in the last year. Labour leader Keir Starmer opposed the move when it was first suggested in January, and the Mirror understands his position has not changed. He said: “I think that MPs do not need a pay rise and we should all be saying that we don’t need that pay rise and it shouldn’t go ahead. “The mechanism is independent but I think it’s for me, as leader of the opposition, to say that I do not think we should have that pay rise.” And in January, Number  urged restraint from IPSA - given the pay rise will coincide with energy bills soaring for millions of families and a National Insurance hike tax for workers. The Prime Ministeraposs spokesman said: “I would say that would we would expect restraint on matters like this given current circumstances but beyond that I think it is right that we let IPSA set out the proposals as an independent body.”  Askedthe PM wouldn’t accept a pay rise himself, the spokesman replied: “I’m simply saying they haven’t set out any detail yet so I wouldn’t wish to comment while that independent process is taking place. “Beyond that we would expect to see restraint on these issues.”Richard Lloyd, IPSA’s Chair, said: “This is the first increase in pay for MPs in two years and follows the average of increases across the public sector last year. story: © Martin Rowson." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" Ukraine will prove fatal, Kevin Maguire says Image: Martin RowsonopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Feb |commentsPariah Putin’s paranoid desperation is increasingly dangerous yet tightening global strangulation should finally signal the end for this Kremlin crackpot. Ukraine will prove the fatal, final mistake by a fascistic gangster who egotistically believed his own invincible propaganda after strategic triumphs in Crimea and Syria, and the  Trump and Brexit blows delivered to the US and UK. Vlad the Invader’s twitchy finger on the nuclear trigger and the offer of Potemkin negotiations are both signs even he fears this is an impending personal Armageddon. This is fuelled by brave Ukrainians fighting heroically and Russians courageously protesting “No to War”, which is inspiring resistance around the world. Supplying anti-tank, helicopter and aircraft missiles strengthens defenders and weakens attackers already suffering punishing losses. Britain, the rest of Europe and the US finally uniting over economic and cultural sanctions will eventually bankrupt the Putin machine and perhaps drive a deep wedge between the tyrant and his billionaire cronies who enjoy opulent luxury wherever they please.  And China abstaining instead of vetoing a UN Security Council motion by the US condemning the brutal invasion emphasised Putin’s isolation, as a new ally quickly distanced itself from an ageing, deranged dictator. The bloody conflict could still belong: reducing Ukrainian neighbourhoods to rubble, inflicting unbearable heartache and costing countless lives. What is becoming clearer, however, is that Putin is also likely to be one of the victims. But let’s not buy charlatan Boris Johnson’s propaganda that he is suddenly an international statesman, a Prime Minister orchestrating the resistance. Johnson let Putin walk all over him and Britain, with oligarchs smirking unconcerned whenever ruling Conservatives, reliant on Russian-linked money, talked tough then acted soft.Charismatic, cool-headed, defiant Ukrainian Volodymyr Zelensky is what a real leader looks and sounds like. Germany’s centre-Left Olaf Scholz is also rising to the occasion, standing up to Putin at considerable financial expense. A European Union that Johnson ripped Britain from as part of a career move was firmer on sanctions until shamed Johnson started running to catch up. Locking out Ukrainian refugees fleeing terror unless they apply to be fruit pickers is disgraceful and inhuman, when Poland, Romania and Hungary open their borders. Why not seize the spacious British properties of Russian oligarchs to house Putin’s casualties  I’ve watched and known Johnson for longer than the  years Putin has misruled Russia. So I’m aware of the cynicism of the great charlatan. From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.  The first casualty of war is Partygate, with Johnson relieved that the shells and missiles are effectively providing a smokescreen. If he’s hit by a fine, the PM will pray it is today. Now wouldn’t be the moment to remove a lawbreaker in Downing Street, his apologists will argue. They’d be wrong, of course. Chamberlain was dumped by MPs to be replaced by Churchill during the Second World War then, before Japan finally surrendered, the country swapped Churchill for Attlee. Labour leader Keir Starmer will inevitably receive less airtime than the PM but should have calculated that he must be constructively critical rather than mercilessly pummelling the Tory rogue. War in Europe might save Johnsonnot an invaded country or Putin. Simon Howard ran his familyaposs famous stately home for  years, and was accused in court of being a paedophile and sex attacker. His death was confirmed yesterday after an ongoing illness and recent complications with diabetes. Criminal charges were brought against the -year-old married father of two last year. But after he suffered irreparable brain damage following a fall in , a judge ruled he was not fit to attend court. A trial of facts held at York Crown Court in his absence in November last year concluded Howard had sexually assaulted a six-year-old girl at Castle Howard in .  The disgraced aristocrat was also charged with the attempted rape of a woman in , while she spent the night at Castle Howard, in North Yorkshire, in . But Howard - who had always maintained his innocence - was placed on the sex offenders register for five years. On Monday, his family released a statement confirming his death, which read: We are able to confirm that very sadly, Simon Howard has died, following an ongoing illness and recent complications with his diabetes. story: Aunt gives birth to nieces baby after volunteering to be her surrogateBethan Williams stepped in when niece Shelley Badea, , was desperate to become a mum but could not carry her own child. story: Blind dog who wants to be cuddled like a baby is looking for new homeTwo-year-old Palomo has been described as a tender and very cuddly dog despite everything he has been through - and would make a wonderful addition to any householdPalomo loves human company Image: Blind Dog Rescue UKByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsDespite being abused and thrown aside, a disabled dog has shown an incredible bond with humans. Palomo, who is completely blind, was found curled up under a car trembling with fear but instead of growling at his rescuer, he hugged her. The two-year-old dog is said to wiggle with happiness when in the company of humans but despite this, he has been unable to secure his own home.The crossbreed, who is currently being fostered by a family in Cornwall, is up for adoption with Blind Dog Rescue UK.A spokesperson from Blind Dog Rescue UK said: Palomo was abandoned in a street near the home of one of our shelter volunteers.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.  It was neighbours who warned her and she immediately went to look for him. Our volunteer gave him a treat and he was so happy with this gesture that he came out of his hiding place without any problem. At no time did he growl or bite her. On the contrary, he hugged her.Palomo has been described as a happy little dog who has perfectly adapted to his blindness, which vets believe is a genetic trait.He immediately integrated into his foster family and became the darling of the whole neighbourhood, the spokesperson added. He is tender and very cuddly with everyone and begging to be in your arms like a little baby.He never makes any gesture or sign of aggression and only seeks to be able to have fun or get closer to you. Every morning, the volunteer brings him to the shelter with her so that he does not feel abandoned again. He loves being with people and when adopting this should be taken into account. Little Palomo can live with other dogs, cats and children over aged  - and would love to have his own garden where he can run around a play with other animals. The spokesperson added: Palomo is a very happy and affectionate young dog with everything and everyone that crosses his path. He is always looking to make friends and despite his blindness, he is absolutely not shy or reserved.  Blind Dog Rescue UK works to rehome blind and partially sighted dogs who have been subjected to the “worst of humanity yet still have an astonishing capacity to adapt, love and become perfect ambassadors for blind dogs everywhere”. Many of the dogs in their care have been victims of abuse, neglect, disease or trauma - and struggle to survive in shelters. A Blind Dog Rescue UK statement reads: “It is incredibly dficult for sighted dogs to survive anyof time in these shelters let alone blind or partially sighted dogs. “We need to get to these dogs quickly and secure their immediate release and treatment.“These dogs may have been deliberately blinded, involved in road traffic accidents or long term sufferers of painful conditions such as glaucoma.“They need veterinary care and to be given the safety and comfort of a foster home in which to start healing. “Here they are given love and affection and a warm bed - possibly the first they will have experienced in their letimes. story: Dad over drink-drive limit when he crashed killing family on way to Tyson Fury fightJohnny Cash was driving a car that crashed killing himself and three members of his family last October in Maidstone, and it has now emerged that he was over the drink driving limitJohnny Cash and his son Johnboy lost their lives in the crash Image: UkNewsinPicturesByLucy WilliamsonReporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar  A father who crashed a car killing himself and three members of his family on their way to watch a Tyson Fury fight was over the drink driving limit, an inquest has heard.The driver Johnny Cash, , his son Johnboy Cash, , and two nephews Miles Anthony Cash, , and Jack Cosgrove, , were killed in the horror crash when the Toyota Hilux pick-up truck left the road in Kent last October. Younger son, Jerry Cash, , was the only survivor after he was left in a coma for months before being finally discharged from hospital in January.The men had been on their way to watch boxer Tyson Furyaposs trilogy fight with American Deontay Wilder when the pick-up truck, driven by Johnny Cash, crashed into a tree. He was almost one-and-a-half times over the legal drink-drive limit, registering at mg per ml of blood. His urine was mg per ml, the inquest heard. Forensic toxicologist Nicola Ingram said he would have been able to walk around fine, but not legally allowed to drive. John Boy, his -year-old son, registered mg p ml for blood sample and mg p ml for urine. Miles Cash had mg p ml of blood and mg p ml in urine. He also had .mg of benzoylecgonine, which is a by-product of cocaine.  Jack Cosgrove had mg p ml of blood and mg p ml of urine. He also had traces of benzoylecgonine in his system, the inquest was told. Pathologist Dr Rouse explained driver Johnny Cash suffered serious multiple injuries to his back, leg, chest, rib and arm injuries. His cause of death, similar to his son John Boy, was given as multiple injuries.  Dr Rouse said there was no sign to suggest there was any injuries from wearing a seatbelt. Although he suggested evidence from detectives will know more about the seatbelt question. John Boy, , suffered facial, leg and head injuries, including a fractured skull. Miles Cash, , also suffered a fractured skull, as well as facial, arm and leg injuries. His cause of death was multiple injuries. Jacko Cosgrove, , also suffered a fractured skull and died of multiple injuries including facial and spinal injuries, the hearing was told. The Toyota was the last of three vehicles heading from a nearby golf club to a kebab shop to get some food before the Fury fight, the hearing was told.  The truck made its way into a drainage ditch before crashing into an oak tree, rotating  degrees into the opposite side of the road. Speaking in the days following the crash, Boxer Tyson Fury paid tribute to the four fans who tragically missed his decisive knockout and sent his condolences to their heartbroken family.He said in a video shared by family and friends on Instagram : Iaposd like to send my condolences and rest in peace to the Cash family and the Cosgrove family on their recent loss.God bless them. Make them a good bed in heaven. In the mighty name of Jesus. Amen. The inquest heard how a witness, Claire Edwards, was driving along the road when she saw the crash. After pulling over she rang . After that she heard screaming and a group of people gathered around the vehicle.  When police arrived at the scene, two of the men were found outside the vehicle - one was thought to be Miles. Dr Rouse explained that Jacko, Miles and John Boy most likely died instantaneously from their injuries, while he believed Johnny died straight away, but he couldnapost be as certain as the three boys due to the dference in his injuries. Hundreds of people from all over the country subsequently attended a mass at St Francis Church in Maidstone, as well as attending three of the menaposs funerals at Holy Family Church in Park Wood. Streets were packed with cars and people as the lives of Johnny Cash and Jack Boy Cash, who lived in Headcorn, and Mr Cosgrove, of Shadoxhurst, Kent, were celebrated. A funeral for Miles Cash, of Cranbrook, was held in Reading. The inquest continues. story: Dad-of-two who consumed caffeine drink equivalent to hundreds of coffees diesDad-of-two Thomas Anthony Mansfield, from Wales, tragically died after miscalculating the quantity of caffeine in his pre-workout drink, causing a cardiac arrestHis heartbroken widow Suzannah said her really healthy husband then began clutching his chest on the sofa. Image: Wales News ServiceByHarri EvansLucy WilliamsonReporter:,  Mar A healthy dad-of-two has tragically died after drinking the equivalent of hundreds of cups of coffee in a miscalculation of how much caffeine he was consuming, an inquest heard today. Thomas Anthony Mansfield, age , from Colwyn Bay in North Wales, passed away on January , , after being confused about the amount of caffeine in his pre-workout drink.Mr Mansfield, who worked as a security guard and a personal trainer consumed powder from Blackburn Distributions, a UK-based sport supplement company, North Wales Live reports.The recommended serving for the caffeine powder, as stated on the packaging at the time, is between -mg twice a day. However the digital scale used by Mr Mansfield to measure the powder had a starting weight of g - which was several times the maximum amount of a single serving of the caffeine powder, the inquest heard at Ruthin County Hall on Tuesday. John Gittins, senior coroner for North Wales east and central, heard that Mr Mansfield was likely aiming for a mid range serving when attempting to measure the powder but instead consumed too much of the supplement.  In a statement, Mr Mansfieldaposs widow, Suzannah, said her late husband was really healthy and would normally drink no more than two cups of coffee a day. She said that her husband necked the remainder of the drink after taking a sip and began clutching his chest shortly afterwards before lying down on the sofa. Moments later, she saw him frothing at the mouth and ran out of the house in order to seek help from her neighbours and family members who lived nearby. An ambulance arrived on the scene within minutes and the crew used a defibrillator due to Mr Mansfieldaposs grossly abnormal heart rhythm as he had gone into cardiac arrest.He was then taken to hospital where resuscitation attempts were eventually stopped at pm and the -year-old was pronounced dead. Following a post-mortem examination, a medical cause of death of caffeine toxicity was given as Mr Mansfield was found to have mg of caffeine per litre of blood, the coroner heard. Caffeine toxicity can be caused by levels at mg per litre of blood or higher. In his conclusion, Mr Gittins recorded Mr Mansfieldaposs death as misadventure due to the unintended result of his own actions in consuming the caffeine powder. Mr Gittins added that he has since been massively reassured that action has been taken to help prevent similar cases from occurring in the future with this brand of caffeine powder due to the provision of a scoop and an A instruction sheet in all new packets. Had these scoops been provided at the time, Mr Mansfield would likely still be alive today, the coroner said in his conclusion.  The instructions and warnings on the caffeine powder packet was not in breach of regulations at the time, the coroner heard. Thomas and Suzannah have two children together, Tommy and Millie, and well-wishers rallied round to fundraise for the family following Tomaposs death. Writing on social media, Suzy said she was absolutely heartbroken by the tragedy. She said: My world has been ripped apart and my kids have lost their daddy. Iaposve lost the love of my le. Tom passed away at the hospital, the family tried so hard but it wasnapost enough. He was my whole le Iaposll never get over this. You were my le Tom. Iaposm missing you so much and trying so hard for the kids keep it together, I love you more than I could love anyone , Iaposll always love you. title: dog owners face new parkrun
story: Dog owners face new parkrun rules after evidence of risk to runners safetyRunners will no longer be permitted to use waist harnesses at UK parkruns after clear evidence shows an increased risk to parkrunners safety when sharing a track with a dog on an unsuitable leadNew rules are being introduced at parkrun Image: Lennox HeraldByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsIn a bid to improve safety and reduce risk, parkrun is changing its rules for runners who participate with their dogs.From Saturday, April , runners will no longer be permitted to use waist harnesses when exercising with their pets a UK parkruns. It comes after clear evidence shows an increased risk to peopleaposs safety when running alongside another participant with a dog, with some becoming tangled in or tripping over the dogaposs lead.A statement reads: We carefully record and review all parkrun-related incidents, and our global incident database allows us to make operational decisions based on the reality of what’s happening in our parks and open spaces.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. Over ten percent of incidents at parkrun events involve dogs, and as such we have spent signicant time considering the nature, frequency, and severity of dog-related incidents. Our evidence shows that, when participants use waist harnesses, there is an increased risk of serious incidents, particularly trips and falls, compared to when using handheld leads. These are typically associated with dogs running in front of other participants, and are occurring when people are together in groups, when people with dogs are overtaking others, and when people with dogs are being overtaken. Unfortunately, the nature of parkrunning with a waist harness is such that the lead allows dogs to move from side to side, in front of the participant, which can result in the dog suddenly and unexpectedly crossing in front of other participants on the course.Under the new rules, dogs should be kept on a short, handheld, non-extendable lead by the side of the participant and should remain within reach at all time. As always, only one dog is allowed per participant and care must be taken to avoid tripping other parkrunners. The statement added: Since the earliest days of parkrun, we’ve openly welcomed people participating with their dogs. Paul Sinton-Hewitt, the founder of parkrun, would participate in the Bushy Park Time Trial with his, and we’ve always felt that it was not only something that emphasised the informal nature of our events, but provided an opportunity for dog owners to participate where they otherwise might be excluded. Over the last  years however, we have grown from a single event into a global movement, with hundreds of thousands of weekly participants, across  dferent countries. As such we continually review our processes in order to balance accessibility and inclusivity with the safety of our participants and other park users. Importantly, we remain of the belief that, overall, the benefits of allowing participation with dogs far outweigh the risks of doing so. Our commitment has always been, and always will be, to support participation with dogs wherever it is appropriate to do so. Do you have a dog story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc. story: Families outline horrors of being trapped in homes plagued by damp and ratsAnthony Bleakley lives with his family of six in a housing association home in Heywood, Manchester - he has been forced to use a playhouse to cover a gaping hole in the floorAnthony Bleakleys home is plagued by damp and rotten floorboards Image: MEN MediaByJosie Le VayAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsFamilies are sharing their horror of feeling trapped in their own homes that are plagued by rats and damp. Anthony Bleakley lives with his family of six in a housing association home in Heywood, Manchester.He told ManchesterEveningNews : We only put this wallpaper up six months ago, it just falls off. But itaposs the hole in the floor below it thataposs the most shocking.We took up the laminate to show more evidence [of the damp]. I was standing on it and it just fell through. Under the floorboards, he says he can see a pool of water.  He added: A lot of the water has gone now but there still is some. When it rains it fills up a lot. Anthony, who has been living in the house for three years, has covered the gaping hole with a playhouse. He said: Iaposm a groundworker by trade so I know whataposs gone on. On their road, the rising damp has affected multiple houses and is a failure of damp proof courses, according to Matthew Condrad, the director of Tenant Claim, who is representing Anthonyaposs family. He says the type of damp proofing the housing association used only has a lespan of around  years - and now it has expired. Two of the four kids in the home have asthma. According to the NHS website,there is mould and damp in the home youaposre more likely to have respiratory problems, respiratory infections, allergies or asthma. Damp and mould can also affect the immune system.Natalie Lake is another resident who lives on the road and fears for her childrenaposs health. Her daughter, Jorja-Maria Lake, has recently been diagnosed with asthma. She said: Sheaposs only three. Her asthma gets so bad she ends up in hospital. Sheaposs very young. Natalieaposs home has many of the same damp problems as Anthonyaposs, she says.  She lted up the laminate in dferent corners of her living room to expose the rotten floorboards. She said: When I walk around the house at night I can feel the floor breaking. Iaposm sure thereaposs water underneath. Itaposs just everywhere. Natalie and Anthony have said that theyaposve both been going to their housing association - Rochdale Boroughwide Housing - for help. But so far, they claim that nothing has been done to properly combat the damp.  Natalie claims that when she had rats, it took them around three years to sort. She added: My mental health went through the roof with the rats. I just feel really upset and angry and frustrated. Anthony said: We keep reporting things but nothing is happening. They keep fobbing us off. They think they can get away with it because we live here and theyaposve got us trapped. The couple had plans to buy their home through Right to Buy in what would be a aposbig savingapos, but are now put off by the aposdisrepairapos of the property. He added: We keep wanting to get the house done up but thereaposs no point.  Lawyer Matthew Condrad told MEN: The properties are affected by rising damp, which is rotting the floorboards, ruining furnishings, and threatening the health of residents. Floorboards are collapsing, and pools of water are visible underneath, from which water is rising into the floorboards, skirting boards and lower walls. This rising damp is due to failure of the damp proof courses. A chemical injection damp proof course has been inserted to alleviate damp, but its approximate -year lespan has expired, meaning that urgent repairs are required in the area. Rat infestations are also a reoccurring problem, causing an additional health risk to residents. A spokesperson from Rochdale Boroughwide Housing said: We received a report of a rat infestation behind one set of homes on Cedar Avenue, Heywood in late . Following a detailed survey, we commissioned extensive drainage work to recty the problem. This was completed in late January . We have not received any further reports of rats in this area. We recently received a report of damp in a home on Cedar Avenue. Our joiner attended on Friday, February , and confirmed that further work is required. We will undertake this work as quickly as possible. RBH tenants who need to report an issue can do so quickly and easily by phone, by e-mail to customerexperience@rbh.org.uk or via the MyRBH online portal. title: highway code rule blocking peoples
story: Highway code rule for blocking peoples driveways and strange legal loophole explainedYou might think there isnt much anyone can do when a person is blocking your drive, but the Highway Code suggests dferently. The police and legal experts have some good advice for people in this situationThere often isnt anything the police or council can do about a car blocking a driveway Image: Universal Images Group via Getty ImagesByBenjamin LynchTrends Writer:,  Mar |comments For residents on tightly packed and busy streets, a blocked driveway can be a complete nightmare. Not knowing how long it will be until the car is moved and you can carry on with your day, be it the school run, going to work or any other reason can put plans on hold.A blocked driveway may just be an unfortunate part of where a person lives, but sometimes angry residents are justied in their annoyance. Certain conditions under the Highway Code mean that a car should be movedit is blocking a driveway.Unfortunately there is also a legal loophole that means motorists can park in annoying places. So what are the conditions under the code that mean cars can be moved Where in the Highway Code does it say you canapost park in front of a driveway   Rule  of the Highway Code states that people should not stop aposin front of an entrance to a propertyapos. However, this only relates tothe car is also blocking the road. Charlotte Dixon, a solicitor at DAS Law, told The Mirror in : The Highway Code can only helpthe parked car is causing an obstruction to the road but not in relation to private land.  Also, not all Highway Codes are legally binding and there is a dference between you aposmust notapos and aposdo notapos. Rule  comes under the latter and stipulates people should not stop unless forced to do so by stationary traffic. A legal loophole says that any car can park on your driveway and local authorities cannot do anything about it because it is private property. It can be removedthe police suspect it to have been abandoned, butthe car has a valid MOT, is taxed and insured and is not in a dangerous condition then there is little the police or council can do. Someone is blocking my driveway, what are my rights   There are several steps you can takea person is blocking your driveway. You should first checkthe space outside your house is designated parking. If it is not, then strangers have a right to park there just as much as you. If someone is parked in your designated space, you can contact your local authority, but there is always the chance the driver has not realised and the issue may be solved with a polite note or conversation.  Dixon said: The first step with any anti-social parking problem is to contact your local authority or the police however there is little the law can do to support home owners – evena car blocks your driveway. One option that’s available is to pursue a legal claim for nuisance on the grounds that the driver is interfering with your use and enjoyment of your property – but to do so you’d need to know the identity of the offending vehicle’s driver. The Met Police also advises people to contact their local authority first. They said: If someone has blocked your driveway so you can’t drive in, we appreciate this can be very frustrating. If you can find the owner of the vehicle, we’d first recommend asking them politely to move it. If you can’t find them, try leaving a note on their windscreen. After all, they may not realise they have caused a problem.
