title: everything you need to know about the one off 200
story: Around , people in Northern Ireland are automatically eligible for a one-off payment of £, which will start being paid to iniduals from next Thursdayonwards.Who can receive the payment The one-off payment of £ will provide support for people struggling to meet rising energy costs due to the global fuel crisis.Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey said that from March  onwards, those in receipt of specied benefits will start automatically receiving the sum of £ directly into their bank accounts.There is no need for a special application to be made. Read MoreEnergy prices will continue to rise for next  months at least, says Utility RegulatorIt will be made automatically to around , eligible people in receipt of specied benefits. The payment will be made through existing payment channels, without the need for an application.Iniduals will be eligible for this payment , during the week of December  to December , , they were in receipt of one or more of the following benefits:Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up • Pension Credit• Universal Credit• Income-related Employment and Support Allowance• Income-based Jobseekers Allowance or• Income Support.If you received any of these benefits during this time last December, you should automatically see £ arrive in your bank account from next Thursday onwards.Iniduals living in care homes from December  to December ,  inclusive are not eligible for this payment.Those in receipt of payment of contribution based Employment Support Allowance only or contribution based Jobseekers Allowance only are also not eligible.Read MoreMinister Deirdre Hargey confirms £ energy support payments to begin from March Ms Hargey has encouraged people to further contact her department’s Make the Call service, which is in place to connect people with the benefits, supports and services to which they are entitled.To #Make the Call# you can phone   , text ADVICE to , visit nidirect.gov.uk makethecall or email makethecall@dfcni.gov.uk.You may also be eligible for Discretionary Support or the Universal Credit contingency fund.What other financial help is available The Department for Communities said it has also provided a £m contribution to an Emergency Fuel Payment Scheme, a crisis fund operated by Bryson Charitable Group for households in immediate need and which may be at risk of disconnection, or who have been disconnected from their energy supply.The scheme launched on January  and as of February , almost , applications have been received, of which almost , were eligible. The department added that almost all eligible applicants received support within  hours.The scheme provides eligible households with one-off support of up to £ worth of electricity, gas, or oil.Over , people will receive a £ payment from  March to help heat their homes. I know that workers and families are struggling with the cost-of-living crisis and huge hikes to energy prices and I am committed to doing all I can to support them.— Deirdre HargeyMarch , Applications can be made up until the end of this month  and must be made via an online form, which will be available on the Bryson Charitable Group website from am and pm Monday-Thursday and am on Friday.You can check your eligibility for this payment scheme here. Criteria includes having received an electricity gas bill within the last five days, which you cannot afford to pay, and or having a total gross annual household income of less than £, .The Utility Regulator has also advised members of the public that are struggling with the rising energy costs, to try seeking the help of charities Credit: Harland  Wolff TwitterAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe fate of a huge oil tanker in a Belfast shipyard is uncertain after the Government said UK ports should refuse access to Russian boats.The Eduard Toll docked at Harland  Wolff’s shipyard earlier this month — where it is currently being worked on — before the invasion of Ukraine.The mammoth liquefied natural gastanker is the largest to enter the shipyard in recent years, and dwarfs Harland  Wolff’s most famous vessel, the ill-fated Titanic.It is designed to operate year-round from Russia’s Yamal peninsula and to break ice up to .m thick. Harland  Wolff on Monday night said it will “continue to support the UK Government’s position”, following Transport Secretary Grant Schapps’ call for all UK ports to deny access to Russian flagged, registered or operated vessels.Mr Shapps tweeted on Monday: “Given Putin’s action in Ukraine I’ve made clear these vessels are NOT welcome here with prohibiting legislation to follow.”In a letter to UK ports, he said the maritime sector “must play our part” in sanctioning Russia over Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “Russia’s assault on Ukraine is an unprovoked, premeditated attack against a sovereign democratic state. The UK Government has been clear there would be massive consequences and a severe cost for any Russian military incursion into Ukraine, and, in co-ordination with our international allies and partners, we are developing an unprecedented package of further sanctions,” he said.“The maritime sector is fundamental to international trade and we must play our part in restricting Russia’s economic interests and holding the Russian government to account.“In these circumstances the Department for Transport does not consider it appropriate for Russian vessels to continue to enter UK ports.“From this point onwards, UK ports are asked not to provide access to any ship which they have reason to believe is: owned, controlled, chartered, or operated by any person connected with Russia owned, controlled, chartered or operated by designated persons flying the Russian flag registered in Russia.“We will seek to support UK ports in identying Russian ships within scope of the above and will communicate directly with relevant ports when we identy ships bound for UK ports who fall within scope of the above.“Further detailed sanctions against Russian shipping are being developed and further details will be shared very shortly.”Harland  Wolff said in a statement to the Belfast : “We are aware of a request issued by the Department for Transport instructing UK ports not to provide access to any ship which is owned or controlled by any person connected with Russia, flying the Russian flag or registered in Russia.“Harland  Wolff has a long tradition of working with UK Government and will continue to support the UK Government’s position.”It is unclear whether the UK Government’s request only concerns incoming Russian vessels, or also those already docked or undergoing repairs.It is also unclear whether or not the Eduard Toll — which measures up at a signicant draught of .m and aof m — we be allowed to leave the Belfast dock amid the current climate.Harland  Wolff’s Belfast shipyard is the site of one of Europe’s largest heavy engineering facilities with deep-water access, and also two of Europe’s largest dry docks. The famous shipyard was saved from closure back in  after being acquired by UK-based energy company Infrastrata. Following the acquisition of Harland  Wolffin August , the firm has focused on opportunities in both ship repair and shipbuilding.Related topicsUkraineMore On UkraineFuel prices soar in space of a Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium #Shocked# Poots denies leaking party leader’s talks to mediaI didn’t know Donaldson and Beattie were even meeting, insists Agriculture MinisterExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseEdwin PootsDoug BeattieSir Jeffrey Donaldson FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEdwin PootsGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailAgriculture Minister Edwin Poots has said he was “shocked” when he heard claims that his party leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson had engaged in talks about rejoining the UUP.Allegations have circulated that Mr Poots, who defeated Sir Jeffrey in a leadership contest last May before being unceremoniously ousted a few weeks later, was the source of leaked information about the meeting.But in response to those allegations, Mr Poots told the Belfast : “That’s not how I do politics. Any rumours that there are on such are entirely without foundation. There is no evidence base for such.“I wasn’t aware of what happened and, therefore, couldn’t have been the source.“In fact, I was somewhat shocked when I heard that had happened, and I didn’t hear that had happened until last Wednesday, when the story was broken.”Askedhe was disappointed when he learned of the meeting, Mr Poots replied: “Well, that’s an internal party matter. I’ll have those discussions with party colleagues at this stage, but it was news to me.”Earlier yesterday, the Agriculture Minister took to social media to set the record straight, saying his name had been “mentioned a number of times” as the source of leaked information. Neither he nor people who supported his leadership were aware of the meeting, Mr Poots said. Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He asked the media to “desist from spreading myths which have zero substance on behalf of people seeking to cause ision in the DUP”.Details of a meeting between the unionist leaders emerged last week, but Sir Jeffrey described any suggestion he was about to join the UUP as nonsense.He said Mr Beattie approached him because he was keen to poach him.At the meeting, Sir Jeffrey explained, Mr Beattie called on him to consider rejoining the UUP. They also discussed issues about the future of unionism, he added.Sir Jeffrey has maintained that he politely declined the offer and vowed to continue engagement with unionists from across all parties and work towards achieving greater cooperation.However, Mr Beattie insisted that his DUP counterpart agreed to the meeting knowing his potential defection to the UUP was at the top of the agenda.He said he has texts of exchanges with Sir Jeffrey and would act to protect his integrityhis version of events was challenged.It is understood that the meeting took place in the privacy of an army barracks.The discussions were held shortly after Sir Jeffrey was narrowly beaten in a leadership contest by Mr Poots.However, Mr Poots held the job for just  days. By the end of June, Sir Jeffrey was party leader.Mr Poots recently failed to secure the party’s nomination to run in South Down in the Assembly elections. He said that he had been engaged with Sir Jeffrey for two months on a process to ensure that the party leader couldto Stormont from Westminster at the elections in May.But at the beginning of February, DUP party officers selected Diane Forsythe as the candidate for South Down ahead of Mr Poots, who was attempting to switch to the constituency from Lagan Valley.South Down MLA Jim Wells previously indicated he believed the decision of the officers should be overturned and Mr Poots should still stand there.At the time, Mr Poots hit out at those within the DUP who had leaked details of the internal party selection processes to the media.Sir Jeffrey left the UUP in  along with Arlene Foster, having been a vocal critic of David Trimble and the Good Friday Agreement. He plans to run in Lagan Valley in the May Stormont election, which will allow him to become First Ministerhis party secures the most votes. Sir Jeffrey has said he wants Mr Poots to stand alongside him and Paul Givan in the Lagan Valley constituency, with a view to winning three seats.Most ReadLisburn luxury property oozing modern style title: Ballynahinch given taste of Bangor blues at the seaside
story: BALLYNAHINCH suffered defeat away to an impressive Bangor outfit who remain unbeaten in the league.lsquoHinch were able to keep Bangor at bay in the early stages with their defence and midfield working hard. Craig Harkness, Ross Connolly and Darren Cassells on the wings were making super tackles when required, while Andrew Mullholand kept the opposition outside the circle.Bangor won a short corner, but Ballynahinch kept the ball out and go on the attack. Leslie Harrison found Alex Millar and he passed the ball to Hugo Melville who attacked up the right hand side before being stopped in his tracks.Before the end of the first quarter Bangor ed to the lsquoHinch circle and took the lead with a tap-in at the back post.With both sides now settled in, the second quarter was full of end to end action. Matthew Martin made a break through the Bangor defence and passed the ball to forward Jason Campbell who won a short corner. Bangor were able to stop the Hinch drag flick from the top of the circle.With Bangor on the front foot and looking to increase their lead they applied the pressure on lsquoHinch. They moved the ball around looking for an opening and went further in front with a shot which came off the back board.lsquoHinch kept the heads and created chances, but they couldnrsquot stop Bangor going - in front.In the third quarter Ballynahinch kept trying to get on the score sheet with Ashley Brown, Andrew Mulholland, Leslie Harrison and Alex Millar all working hard.Hinch started to creep up the pitch and Matthew Martin created a channel for the ball to be fired up to Jason Campbell, whose attempted pass to Michael Carney was unfortunately intercepted.Bangor were able to create several chances in the Hinch circle, only to be stopped by keeper Aaron Donnell, Ashley Brown and Andrew Mulholland. However, they added another goal to the scoreline with a well-placed shot.In the final quarter Hinch broke through the Bangor defence and Craig Harkness narrowly missed pulling a goal back.Bangor were on the attack for most of the closing stages and forced a series of short corners which were kept out as lsquoHinch put every player behind the ball.However, a well placed pass across the circle narrowly missing every Hinch stic and was deflected in at the back post.As Bangor continued to attack, a drag flick from the top of the circle was deflected over the crossbar by keeper Donnell and a number of late short corners and further attempts on goal were kept out by stout defending from Ashley Brown, Leslie Harrison, Matthew Martin and Alex Millar.Player of the match: Ashley Brown.The club wishes to thank the Primrose, Ballynahinch, for their continued sponsorship..prettyPhoto

title: Bhoys batter Carryduff in goal feast at Ballyhornan
story: CELTIC Bhoys breezed through the adverse weather conditions to remain in the hunt for the league title as they swept aside a depleted Carryduff outfit at Ballyhornan on Saturday.Hat-tricks apiece for Celtic marksmen Sean McMahon and Jordan McCoubrey helped the Hoops to an emphatic victory on a weekend when plenty of other fixtures suffered postponement as a result of Storm Eunice.The away side only travelled with a total of  players and so immediately were at a disadvantage as the hosts knew they could call upon their benchneeded.With this in mind, Celtic attacked the opposition from the outset with strike partners McCoubrey and McMahon linking up on numerous occasions within the opening minutes.It didnrsquot take long for the home side to find the back of the net after Barry Treacy lofted a pin-point pass on to the head of McMahon, who steered his effort past Carryduff lsquokeeper Conor Leggett.Although often pressed back into their own half, Carryduff were determined to make a go of it and knew they had to make the most of their seldom opportunities.Midfielder Ciaran Conway saw his free-kick glide gracefully into the arms of Celtic custodian Nathan Curran, before McMahon was again causing problems at the other end.This time he saw his headed effort ruled out for offside. This was a warning sign of things to come as just moments later McCoubrey managed to put the ball into the net courtesy of the outside of his right boot after a scramble in the box.Again, Carryduff showed their resilience and still relied on their counterattacks, the latest coming from captain Conway, although his misjudged pass denied team-mate David Quigley a chance at goal.The pressure would continue to mount on the Carryduff back line and soon it was - as McCoubrey registered his second of the match mdash albeit through an unorthodox but neat finish.Celtic defender Blaine Connolly saw his effort fantastically thwarted by Carryduff lsquokeeper Leggett, who pounced to the bottom right corner of his net with a strong outstretched arm to deny further punishment.The weather began to give its input into the game as temperatures ped bitterly and the wind began to blow harshly at intervals.Although this cannot be cited as the determining factor in this contest by any stretch of the imagination, it certainly played its part when Carryduffrsquos Emmet Curran saw his through ball carried beyond its intended target.Carryduff did manufacture a rare breakaway and it looked asstriker Jonathan Wilkinson would open the away sidersquos account when a pass from midfield left him with just lsquokeeper Curran to beat.However, an impressive last-ditch tackle from defender Gary Carberry allowed the Celtic number five to hook the ball to safety, thus further frustrating the opposition.Celticrsquos Shaun Megahey saw his left-footed effort saved before Carryduffrsquos Joseph McBrien swept up the loose ball and in the last notable action of the half, Conway witnessed his lowly struck effort palmed away from danger by the Hoopsrsquo number one.As the second half kicked off, the home side showed no signs of relenting as they pushed for more goals.Conaill Kerr saw his point-blank effort superbly saved from six yards by lsquokeeper Leggett, who, despite the score line, made numerous contributions to prevent his side conceding into double figures.This over-eagerness from the hosts would cost them as they were caught short at the back, leaving Raymond Grant unmarked  yards from goal.The striker quickly picked his spot and unleashed a lovely curled effort into the top right hand corner to get his side off the mark.Unfortunately for Carryduff, this was as good as it got as Celtic replied almost immediately with McMahon grabbing his second of the matchafter rounding the lsquokeeper for an easy tap in.Things went from bad to worse for the away team when Stephen Galbraith slipped a pass into the path of team-mate Conaill Kerr, who made no mistake with his finish in the one-on-one scenario.At this point Carryduff were aiming for damage limitation but Celtic smelt blood. McMahon completed his hat-trick with an eye-catching acrobatic effort before McCoubrey, tapped in his third of the day.Hoops defender Carberry picked up a yellow card after some unsavoury words with the official and captain Michael Rice was left red-faced after midfielder Curran knocked the ball between his legs, but the home outfit didnrsquot let that deter them from their onslaught.Carberry atoned for his booking in the form of a late header from a Galbraith corner delivery to round off the scoring at -.After the match, hat-trick hero Sean McMahon gave his thoughts on his sidersquos resounding victory.ldquoIt was a good performance, he said. ldquoWe knew they only had  players so we had a good chance of winning but you have to play the  minutes and make sure you get the victory at the end of the day.ldquoWersquove put pressure on the league leaders, itrsquos good to score three goals but the main thing is to get the three points.He added: ldquoI donrsquot usually score headers so thatrsquos my pick of the goals for me.Celtic Bhoys: N Curran, S Megahey, B Connolly, R Fitzpatrick, G Carberry, M Rice , B Treacy, C McCartan, S McMahon, J McCoubrey, C Kerr. Subs: P Brady, S Galbraith, R Quinn. Yellow cards: G Carberry.Carryduff Athletic: C Leggett, J McGowan, E Woods, J McBrien, C Kerr, E Curran, D Quigley, C Conway , R Grant, J Wilkinson, G Moriarty..prettyPhoto

title: Catholic woman to get £560k  from MoD in settlement for repeated harassment
story: A CATHOLIC civilian worker from Co Down who had to leave her job over harassment by her Army boss is set to receive more than pound, in compensation.Bronagh Murraytook a religious and sexual discrimination case against the Ministry of Defenceafter retiring due to ill health in .The award, made by the Fair Employment Tribunal in Belfast, is believed to be one of the biggest of its kind.Ms Murray, who said the ruling was a complete vindication, described what happened as leaving her feeling ldquoabsolutely humiliated and horribly isolated.The mother-of-two had worked as an administrative officer at the MoD for  years, with the comments made by a captain at the Armyrsquos Thiepval Barracks in Lisburn in .Ms Murray said the officer, who cannot be identied for security reasons, repeatedly referenced her religion in front of others in the office.She said the officer remarked: ldquoI need back up, I have an Irish Catholic girl armed and dangerous, come quick, need help.Ms Murray said the officer again referenced her religion in an office conversation about a concert, when he said: ldquoI bet you have tried to steal a cone, that is the Catholic coming out in you.She also claimed sexual discrimination after she was described as ldquothe big cougar.Her boss was disciplined and transferred to another military posting after she made a complaint.Due to a deteriorating psychiatric condition, Ms Murray was pensioned off from the civil service in August .The tribunal awarded Ms Murray about pound, to cover injury to feelings, psychiatric injuries, loss of previous earnings and interest.Future lost earnings for Ms Murray, who had not been due to retire from the civil service until , are expected to come to more than pound,.Her solicitor, Brian Archer, said: ldquoIt is anticipated that the final monies to be paid to Ms Murray by the Ministry of Defence will be in the region of pound,.ldquoThis award is one of the highest that the tribunal has had to adjudicate upon.Ms Murray said she now wanted to start rebuilding her le.ldquoI had an immaculate civil service history from the age of , it was all I ever knew, she said. ldquoBut I was offered no support and just left to get on with it.ldquoIt felt like I was only a female and a Catholic, I was the one making waves and rocking the boat. But I was prepared to see this through. Irsquom a strong, resilient woman ndash right is right and wrong is wrong.Ms Murrayrsquos solicitor said she was ldquonot prepared to be a victim of sectarianism or sexual discrimination.Mr Archer added: ldquoAs a result of this Army captainrsquos conduct, a lady who was a highly-respected and well-regarded civil servant has suffered a severe psychiatric condition, loss of confidence and faces a slow road back to full recovery.ldquoNot only am I amazed and shocked at this officerrsquos conduct, but that no one  in the office where she worked intervened at any stage to stop Ms Murray being repeatedly abused because of her religion and sex.Speaking to the BBC, the solicitor said his clientrsquos le had ldquototally changed as a result of the harassment but he commended her determination in pursuing her case.ldquoPrior to April , she was happy in her occupation as a civil servant, he explained.ldquoThis wasnrsquot an isolated incident, this happened several times over a period of months. This happened when other military personnel were present in the room and it isnrsquot a question of banter, he said.ldquoThey [MoD] have a duty of care to their staff ndash their civilian staff as well as military staff and the Army should not tolerate such behaviour now, then or in the future..prettyPhoto

title: Charity walk to be held in memory of local man
story: A CHARITY walk in aid of NI Chest, Heart and Stroke will take place at the RGU GAA club in Downpatrick on Sunday.The walk is being organised by local Colum Wynn and is memory of his father, Malachy, who died recently.The event is from pm to pm and participants can set their own distance or theof time they wish to walk.Colum is asking people to make a donation on the day and is also urging local businesses to make a donation or provide a raffle prize.Says Colum: ldquoSadly four people in Northern Ireland die every day from heart disease and there are over , people here living witha chest, heart or stroke condition mdash thatrsquos one in five of us.He said the charityrsquos vision was a Northern Ireland free from chest, heart and stroke illnesses.Urging people to come along on Sunday, he added: ldquoDress how you like, and wear your heart on your sleeve and together we can help rebuild thousands of lives and make a lasting change towards heart health.For further information contact Colum on   or via Facebook..prettyPhoto

title: Down Leisure Centre vitality suite to reopen after Covid restrictions
story: THE ultra-modern vitality suite at the Down Leisure Centre is expected to reopen by the start of next month.One of the key attractions of the Downpatrick leisure complex, the suite was closed due to coronavirus restrictions, with its impending reopening confirmed at Monday nightrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee.Prior to the meeting, three local politicians who use the leisure centre had called for the reopening of the suite which includes a mini vitality pool, steam room, heated stone bed and sauna.Cllrs Alan Lewis, Patrick Brown and Cadogan Enright mdash who are regular users of the gym at the leisure centre mdash believe all facilities should now be fully reopen with the final easing of most coronavirus restrictions.Cllr Lewis said the removal of the restrictions ldquopresents an opportunity for people and facilities to get back to some degree of normality.ldquoAs lockdown eases, residents are looking toward to rebuilding their health and fitness, seeking to tackle social isolation by engaging in actives which promote health and wellbeing, he said.Cllr Lewis said the Down Leisure Centre offers state-of-the-art gym facilities which allow users to fully engage in their chosen programme of exercise, with the vitality suite ideal for a post work-out cool down, rehabilitation, or simply catching up with friends.ldquoWith the reopening of other similar facilities in other venues, we should be looking at developing a plan that can ensure the safeof the vitality suite, he said.ldquoAs a member of the Active and Healthy Communities Committee I will be requesting that officers bring forward a plan to ensure a planned and agreed reopening. Itrsquos time to get the leisure centre back on track so letrsquos encourage exercise while promoting healthy and active lestyles.Cllr Brown said as regular gym users, he and his two colleagues want to see the facility open and used properly by paying members.ldquoWe have been contacted by a huge number of people keen to see all the leisure centre facilities open again, with many expressing the health and wellbeing benefits it brought them pre-Covid, he said.ldquoGiven the removal of all restrictions, the local council should no longer use Covid as an excuse to keep this facility closed, especially when the vast majority of similar facilities across the country are open.Concurring, Cllr Enright said gym users want the leisure centrersquos facilities fully open now Covid- restrictions are lted.He added: ldquoI have received phone calls, emails and even personal approaches while using the gym with people making this very point.ldquoIn addition, they also want gym equipment that was taped up during Covid- to be brought back into use, alongside other facilities to ensure the leisure centre gets back to full operating capacity..prettyPhoto

title: Down off and running with deserved point in storm against Meath
story: DOWN will welcome Roscommon to Pairc Esler this Saturday with renewed optimism.James McCartanrsquos side secured their first point of the National League campaign with a deserved draw against Meath in Navan on Sunday.But it could have been better. Caolan Murray had two great chances to win it in stoppage time, but both went begging.Mooney was denied what seemed a certain goal by a brilliant intervention by Meathrsquos Padraqic Harman, whose outstretched arm clipped the ball away just as Mooney was about to shoot to the net.Just a few moments later Mooney mdash and Down mdash suffered further agony when his fisted attempt came back off the crossbar.Even so, Down can considerate themselves fortunate to come away with a point after they failed to score during a second half when they found themselves defending desperately against a Meath side driven on by their fans and a gale force wind.The conditions were horrendous and it was a tribute to both sides that they managed to produce an entertaining game of football mdash in the first half at least.Down had the advantage of the wind in the first half and led by - to - at the break, half of their tally coming from Pat Havern who hit -.Meath must have fancied their chances as they turned around with the wind in their backs, but they couldnrsquot adapt to the terrible conditions and Down held out, surely much to the satisfaction of their manager.The home side took an early lead in the match with a free from their goalkeeper, Harry Hogan.Havern responded for Down  seconds later, but when another free opportunity presented itself for Meath three minutes later Hogan again converted to make it - to -.Successive points from Havern, who used the wind well to execute the scores, edged Down in front for the first time, but in the th minute a brilliant move involving Thomas OrsquoReilly and Jordan Morris ended with Clarke finishing brilliantly to the net for Meathrsquos opening goal.The madcap nature of the contest continued when a rare mistake by Donal Keogan gted Down possession and they took full advantage with Anthony Doherty, Havern and Jack McCartan combining to set up Andrew Gilmore for a fine goal.Gilmore stretched Downrsquos lead with a point from a mark, but again Meath knitted together an excellent move against the wind with Scully playing a neat one-two with Matt Costello before firing to the net to make it - to -.Seconds later OrsquoReilly rattled the crossbar and Jason Scully was wide from the follow-up. Down took advantage when Odhran Murdock won a Meath kick-out and released Havern to beat Hogan at his near post.Gilmore had a great chance to add a third goal for Down, but he fired straight at Hogan and in the th minute Meath closed the gap with Shane Walsh scoring their only point from play.Gilmore replied with a pointed free and five minutes before the break Darren OrsquoHagan stretched Downrsquos lead to - to - with what proved to be his sidersquos last score.Three minutes after the restart Costello couldnrsquot connect to Morrisrsquos centre and the goal chance went begging and it took almost six minutes before Walsh got Meath moving with a point from a free.Meath struggled to break down the visitorsrsquo well marshalled rearguard and it wasnrsquot until the th minute that they closed the gap to the minimum with a Morris free.However more chances came and went as Hogan hit the upright from a free and Morris was denied a goal by a good save from Rory Burns. Hogan arrowed the resultant lsquorsquo wide.Walsh was also off target from a  metre free before Morris levelled the game from a free with  minutes plus injury time remaining.Meath: Harry HoganRobin Clarke , Eoin Harkin, Jordan Muldoon Cathal Hickey, Shane McEntee, Donal Keogan Padraic Harnan, Ronan Jones Ethan Devine, Thomas OrsquoReilly, Matt Costello Jordan Morris , Shane Walsh , Jason Scully .Subs: Cillian OrsquoSullivan for Scully  mins, Eamon Wallace for Wallace m, Jack OrsquoConnor for OrsquoReilly m, Bryan McMahon for Walsh m.Down: Rory Burns Peter Fegan, Finn McElroy, Gerard Collins Darren OrsquoHagan , Niall McPartland, Caolan Mooney Anthony Doherty, Odhran Murdock Liam Kerr, Pat Havern , Ruairi McCormack Conor Poland, Andrew Gilmore , Jack McCartan.Subs: Barry OrsquoHagan for McCartan  mins, Pierce Laverty for McCormack m, Kevin McKernan for Haveran m, Adam Lynch for Collins m, Cory Quinn for B OrsquoHagan m.Referee: Noel Mooney ..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick man Matthew dances his way into next round of RTE’s DWTS
story: LOVE Island star Matthew MacNabb was in need of the immunity vote for last weekendrsquos Dancing With The Stars on RTE.The Downpatrick man scored just  points for a disappointing cha-cha after scoring his highest score the previous week for a poignant contemporary ballroom dance.The dance was dedicated to his American friend Ryan Freeman who died in an accident just before Matthew went on to Love Island last August.Despite keeping up the tremendous practice rate that Matthew and his professional dance partner Laura Nolan are known for, the dance proved a challenge for him on last Sundayrsquos live show.Missy Keating, daughter of Boyzone star Ronan Keating, was the star to leave after the showrsquos first dance-off with her Charleston dance.Judge Brian Redmond told  year-old Matthew after his dance to Dynamite by BTS: "The song was wide awake but the dancing was a bit of a damp squib. I know you were immune from elimination tonight, but I think you were a little bit immune to the cha-cha as well."Matthew told presenter Nicky Byrne: "I didnt think cha-cha would be my strongest suit, but I wanted to go out and do my best and I think I did that.Afterwards, the digital marketer and fitness and mental health motivator, spoke of his disappointment on social media: ldquoWell itrsquos safe to say cha-cha is not my favourite dance.ldquoNot the performance I had hoped for after working well all week but more motivation to kill it next week.ldquoIt was great to have immunity thanks to you all and we are ready to smash it in week eight.The Downpatrick man has a growing fan base, with , followers on Instagram.Check out Matthewrsquos progress on Dancing With The Stars on Sunday at .pm on RTEacute One..prettyPhoto

title: End horror of trafficking
story: A DOWNPATRICK man who leads a global organisation which aims to end human trafficking and modern slavery says the problem is closer to home than people might think.Tim Nelson is CEO of Hope for Justice, a non-profit organisation which actively rescues women, children and men from exploitive situations and gives them the best chance of a restored le afterwards.The Inch man was in demand by major media outlets last week after the Duke of Edinburgh settled a civil case taken against him by Virginia Giuffre, the woman at the centre of the Jeffrey Epstein sex trafficking ring of young girls.Mr Nelson is calling for people to be more aware of the potential for trafficking around them, whether it is online exploitation and grooming of children and young people, slave labour behind products and services we use and sexual exploitation of people.He said: ldquoIf I look at the area I grew up in, recently I was hearing stories of iniduals who had been rescued from businesses in that area. There are iniduals are in the Down area who were being exploited in factories and fishing vessels. The reality of what people may think is a million miles away, until they see how prevalent it is, they donrsquot realise how close it is.Mr Nelson, a former banker, co-founded Hope for Justice in the West Yorkshire area in .By working with former senior detectives, the charity managed to rescue  victims in its first year.ldquoWe hired former senior detectives and police officers to carry out undercover intelligence gathering which led to the recovery of victims. Our youngest rescued from sexual exploitation was just three months old, the oldest was , said Mr Nelson.Hope for Justice now operates in eight countries worldwide, with its biggest area of need in Ethiopia and Uganda. Working with UNICEF, the organisation so far has succeeded in ing , children back to their parents.ldquoOnce you see the joy and emotion of a child being ed to safety, as I have done myself, then you understand why we do the work we do.Mr Nelson has joined forces with a group in Northern Ireland, formerly known as No More Traffick, to set up a base here with the view of having an all-island anti-trafficking strategy once the charity is registered in the Republic of Ireland.ldquoOne in ten people in Northern Ireland will use a prostitute at any time in their le. When you look at that, therersquos not the numbers of women who would actually want to be prostitutes, said Mr Nelson.ldquoI would want men to be aware of the impact they are having on these iniduals.ldquoI would want parents to be aware of the protocols they are putting in for their Wi router and checking their childrenrsquos screens so they can see who they are engaging with it before itrsquos too late as so many people prey on the weak, the marginalised, the poor and the depressed.He added: ldquoI just wish there was a greater awareness right across the board on this issue. Itrsquos that reality that this could be your son or daughter, I must do somethingrsquo. ldquoldquoWhen that penny s, it is someonersquos daughter, you realise then I can do something. Even the smallest act can make a huge dference.ldquoWe have seen people of all walks of le do amazing things to raise money and support our work, and of course to raise awareness of the issue. Awareness leads to action and action leads to change.To donate to Hope for Justice, or find out about fundraising, visit www.hopeforjustice.org.prettyPhoto

title: Eva and Cara in NI Soloist of Year final
story: TWO local girls are competing this weekend to win the BBC NI School Soloist of the Year Competition .Eva Rowan, head girl of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick, and Cara Keaveney, from Assumption Grammar School in Ballynahinch, will be singing against two other finalists to win the prestigious title.Both  year-olds are completing their A-Levels with their respective schools before heading off to university.Eva, from Annacloy, is well-known for her performances with St Patrickrsquos Choral Society in Downpatrick and was set for a starring role in its production Oklahoma!She also played Aerial in its production of The Little Mermaid and was a narrator in Joseph and The Amazing Technicolour Raincoat.Eva won her place in the final by impressing the  with her living rendition of Taylor, The Latte Boy, which showed off her musical theatre skills, and Time Heals Everything from the musical Mac and Mabel.In Saturdayrsquos final for the age group for Years -, she will be singing Taylor, The Latte Boy again along with No-One Is Alone from the Stephen Sondheim musical, Into The Woods.Eva, the youngest child of Micheal and Lucille Rowan, comes from a musical family and hopes to study Musical Theatre at university.Cara Keaveney, who is from Newcastle, is also well-known for her singing prowess locally.The daughter of popular local singer and musician Finbarr Keaveney, Cara sings duets with her father at ious local concert performances but is also performs solo at weddings, funerals and concerts.She will be singing At Last, from Etta James and She Used to be Mine from the show Waitress.The competition will be broadcast on BBC NI at a later date..prettyPhoto

title: First win for Ballynahinch
story: A DOMINANT opening quarter laid the foundation for Ballynahinch to claim their first victory of the season at the th attempt.They mastered tricky conditions at the Mardyke to open up a gap on the scoreboard which the Cork students were unable to overcome.Adam Craig and his side had travelled with confidence to their fellow strugglers after two weeksrsquo rest and some encouraging news on the injury front.Ronan Patterson and Aaron Cairns were fit to start on the wings with Conor Rankin at full back, while Peter Cooper was back at prop, allowing Kyle McCall to move into the hooker slot in the continued absence of Zac McCall and Tom Stewart.Callum Irvine was the only regular missing and his place at No  was taken by Bradley Luney, with Tommy Donnan moving from lock to blind side and Tom Martin coming into the second row. The Gill brothers, Gareth and Kyle, were among the replacements.Ballynahinch used the conditions superbly to burst into a lead they would not surrender.Playing with the wind, they pinned the students back with excellent tactical kicking and after missing an early long range penalty they went for the corner following a UCC offence at the breakdown and Kyle McCall burst from the edge of the maul to score.A great kick and chase moments later led to another penalty and another maul try for McCall. Greg Hutleyrsquos superb conversion took Ballynahinch  points clear after  minutes.The second quarter yielded only a single UCC penalty. Ballynahinch were not quite as accurate as they had been earlier in the game and small errors and indiscipline allowed UCC plenty of possession. However, excellent defence and long clearing kicks meant that the Ballynahinch line was never threatened.The second half was a scrappy affair and Ballynahinch began to fall foul of the referee at the breakdown.UCC kicked a long range penalty to close the gap to six points and missed another moments later as Ballynahinch struggled to put phases together into the wind. However, they sprung to le on  minutes and battled upfield where McCall was denied another maul try for a double movement.Following this disappointment UCC won a big scrum penalty and had the chance to kick to the corner to really turn the screw but misjudged the wind and kicked the ball dead. From the resulting scrum it was the away side who were celebrating as they won a penalty to relieve the pressure and settle the nerves.As the game entered the final quarter it was an error-strewn, stop-start affair, with injury stoppages and errors denying either side the chance to stamp any authority on proceedings.A mistimed Ryan Wilson tackle earned him a yellow card on  minutes and when UCC kicked the resulting penalty to close the gap to three points UCC were probably favourites.However, Ballynahinch produced an excellent spell of forward play with their maul continuing to be a very powerful weapon.They won a penalty from a maul on halfway and went for the corner, using up vital time on the sinbin and subjecting UCC to huge pressure deep in their .A solid scrum allowed Rory Butler the chance to go for the line where UCC gave away a penalty at the breakdown. Ballynahinch piled on the pressure, carrying hard at the line and desperate UCC defence led to another penalty and a yellow card for their replacement prop.The game was now there for the taking and following another big scrum on the UCC line Ballynahinch tried to put Conor Rankin over on the blind side.Multiple phases later UCC looked to have weathered the storm when they stole the ball and kicked clear. A superb chase saw Ballynahinch caught in possession but Cairns made an excellent arcing run to scythe through the cover and head for the line.He was tackled just short but the supporting Hutley was on hand to barge over, taking a knock in the process.He recovered to slot the conversion, sending Ballynahinch  points clear going intothe last five minutes and they saw out the game in relative comfort.Celebrations lasted long into the night and Ballynahinch have now put daylight between themselves and UCC.Third from bottom UCD arrive at Ballymacarn Park on Saturday to take on a rejuvenated local outfit who now have a snf of avoiding the relegation play-off. All support is welcome for a crucial fixture.Ballynahinch : Nacho Cladera Crespo, Kyle McCall, Peter Cooper, Tom Martin, John Donnan, Tommy Donnan, Oli Loughead, Bradley Luney, Conor McAuley, Greg Hutley, Aaron Cairns, Rory Butler, Ryan Wilson, Ronan Patterson, Conor Rankin, David Cooper, Ben Cullen, Gareth Gill, Kyle Gill, Chris Gibson, Callum McLaughlin..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  February 27th%2C 1991
story: BALLYNAHINCH ndash Detectives hunting a three-man gang which robbed a Ballynahinch bank within days of its official opening, have appealed for information on the gangrsquos getaway car.The red Ford Sierra car was parked in a Ballynahinch housing estate for a ldquoconsiderable time both before and after the Thursday-morning robbery, and police believe local people could provide vital evidence about the gang.Police say the robbers got away with a substantial sum of money plus a large amount of American Express travellers cheques in US dollars.The robbery occurred around .am when two men walked into the new Ulster Bank in Main Street, apparently on legitimate business. One sat down while the other went up to the counter and asked for a bag of coins to be changed.As the men waited in the bank a Securicor delivery van arrived and a guard began leaving money bags into the bank.As the guard left a second bag into the bank one of the robbers produced a handgun and pushed him to the floor while the other vaulted the bank counter and grabbed the bags.Both men then left the bank and raced down the alleyway beside Irwinrsquos Superfoods to the red Sierra which was waiting, with a driver, at the entrance to the supermarket car park.The car sped off and was found on Sunday abandoned in a cul-de-sac off Hillfoot Crescent.CASTLEWELLAN ndash Mill bosses this week denied they plan to close the doors on a Castlewellan factory ndash less than three years after the plant was reopened.Speculation has intensied that Castlewellan Yarns, which is based in the former Moss Lane factory on the townrsquos Dublin road, is to be shut.The company is a ision of Linfield Group of textile-companies but a spokesman when asked about possible closure said this week: ldquoThat is not the situation at the moment. The Castlewellan plant was set up to do a specic job. It is having to compete head-on in a dficult world market at this time of depression.ldquoThere has been short-time working and we have operated at  per cent of capacity. Castlewellan is totally dependent on an upturn in the general linen market.The Linfield Group announced in  that it intended to commence production in Castlewellan. It said then it hoped to create up to  jobs in a poundm investment. However, employment levels have failed to reach this mark and the Ulster linen trade generally is currently experiencing one of it biggest slumps for a number of years.ARDGLASS ndash An assurance has been given that the long-awaited improvement package for Ardglass harbour will go ahead, despite a sizeable increase in cost projections.The chief executive of the Northern Ireland Fishery Authority, Mr Ronan Fitzsimons, has said he is confident the work on the scheme will proceed, even though it is expected to cost substantially more than the Governmentrsquos pound.m budget.Work on the project, which involves extending the main pier by  metres and providing rock armouring at the back of the harbour wall, was expected to begin next month.But trawlermen, who have been campaigning more than  years for the scheme, were startled when it emerged late last week that tenders received were vastly above original estimations.It has been claimed that some of the tenders are up to pound, over the initial budget.Mr Fitzsimons said yesterday there would be a delay in the start date but denied rumours that the scheme is being put on ice indefinitely.ldquoThe start will have to be put back but there is no question of the project being ped, he remarked.STRANGFORD ndash The proposal to build a tidal barrage across Strangford Lough has been killed off ldquoonce and for all.Stormont Minister Richard Needham axed the plan because of the damage such a barrage would have caused to the sensitive environment of Strangford Lough.The announcement has been welcomed by environmentalists who described the Ministerrsquos attitude to the Lough as ldquovery positive and encouraging.Mr Needham made his announcement at the annual conference of the Royal Society for the Protection of birds and the Irish Wildbird Conservancy in Newcastle on Saturday.Opening the conference in the Slieve Donard Hotel, Mr Needham said the barrage proposal would no longer be merely shelved but would be dropped completely.ldquoIn the early rsquos there was a proposal to construct a barrage across the Narrows to allow the generation of electricity using tidal power, explained Mr Needham. ldquoAt that time, the proposal was examined from many viewpoints. On economic grounds it just did not measure up, and so it was shelved.ldquoThere is no doubt that the creation of a barrage would severely and irretrievably damaged the superb wildle of the Lough, altering the tidal regime, ruining feeding grounds, and in the process reducing muchthe scenic quality, said the Minister.KILLYLEAGH ndash A government minister is to be asked by Down councillors tomorrow to lt the embargo on marina development at Killyleagh.A deputation of councillors is hoping to persuade Economy Minister, Mr Richard Needham, to allow a marina development on the shores of Strangford Lough.The Minister will be told of the fears that Killyleagh is being turned into a ghost town because of substantial job losses in its industrial base ndash and the belief that a marina could hold out hope of a revival.The townrsquos Ulster Unionist councillor. Mr Sam Osbourne, said ldquowhile we are meeting the Minister about the decision last August to refuse three separate applications for a marina, it goes much wider than that. There is a need for an overall plan for this town.ldquoThe whole place is badly run down and has probably never been at a lower ebb. Killyleagh is a ghost town now. We need some new source of employment and a marina linked to a hotel would be a big boost.DOWNPATRICK ndash Councillors targeting Downpatrickrsquos arts centre for closure may be prevented from carrying out their plans by the terms of the buildingrsquos lease.The -year lease on the building, which was agreed when the council took over the former Town Hall from Lord Dunleath, does not enable the council to sell the property andit is closed for more than  months the building will revert to its original owner.Under the terms agreed, the council took over the building on the basis it would be used solely for the purpose outlined in Article  of the Recreation and Youth Services Order.ldquoThis paragraph specically empowers councils to provide facilities for ldquorecreational, social, physical and cultural activities.The lease on the arts centre states that the owner, Lord Dunleath, would enforce his right to take back the building within  monthsits uses were outside the terms of that clause.This means that several years of council investment, eighteen months worth of running costs, and a pound, grant from the Department of Education would be wasted.DUNDRUM ndash Crisis-threatened Dundrum Regatta has been saved from collapse after villagers rallied to a special meeting last week.The Regatta, one of the oldest summer festivals in Northern Ireland, looked doomed earlier this month but an appeal by organisers has attracted increased community support and ensure the eventrsquos future.The special meeting was called after just five people attended the organising committeersquos annual meeting earlier this month.It was immediately adjourned and an appeal issued to villages to support the reconvened meeting, held in St Donardrsquos hall on Tuesday night.Committee chairman, Mr Paddy Cunningham said: ldquoI was very pleased to see the turnout had increased signicantly and we were able to proceed with the business of organising this yearrsquos Regatta..prettyPhoto

title: Jimmy's 10k back
story: ONE of the most prestigious races in the local running calendar is ing to the streets of Downpatrick after an absence of three years.Jimmyrsquos K, organised by East Down Athletic Club and supported by MB McGrady  Co, Chartered Accountants, will take place on Sunday, March .Given that it will be the opening race of the  K Grand Prix, and one of the first road running fixtures of the Athletics NI calendar, organisers are expecting a packed entry list.Jimmyrsquos K was last raced in Downpatrick in . The  event was cancelled owing the outbreak of the Covid pandemic and last year it was switched to BishopscourtWith numbers capped at , almost % of places have already been allocated.Last yearrsquos winners, Gavin Corey, from Strive Racing Club, and Tracey Atkinson, from North Belfast Harriers, will be ing to try to beat their times.Mal McGrady, a partner at MB McGrady  Co, who are supporting the race for the th year, said: ldquoJimmyrsquos K is a hugely successful event for the local community and it is great to see the race ing to the streets of Downpatrick.ldquoThis year, MB. McGrady  Co is celebrating  years in business. Wersquove seen many changes in that time, but nothing quite like the past few years, so itrsquos refreshing to see popular community events like Jimmyrsquos K ing.He added: ldquoWith a deserved reputation as one of the flagship events on the regionrsquos running calendar and one that has always been a hugely successful event for the local community, we are proud to support itsnext month, with many of our staff and clients taking part in the race.East Down Athletics Club first established Jimmyrsquos K in , in memory of Jimmy Murray, a school teacher and athletics enthusiast, who was one of the founding members of East Down AC in .Explaining how the event has grown in stature, East Down AC chairman, Paul Burns said: ldquoWersquove got exceptionally strong athletics clubs in County Down and the surrounding areas, which ensures a solid level of support from our local runners every year.ldquoThis is then complemented by runners from across Northern Ireland who want to benchmark their times at the start of the season.ldquoThe eventrsquos March timing has really helped participation levels to grow as it marks the start of the competition season mdash being the first race in the K Grand Prix mdash and itrsquos the perfect training milestone for runners who are competing in the Belfast Marathon.ldquoWe are attracting runners from across Northern Ireland and most people, even those from outside the running fraternity know of this event.ldquoThis has been made possible with the help of our continued support from local businesses and sponsors including MB. McGrady  Co.Prizes will be awarded to first, second and third places among male and female runners and age group winners. There are also team prizes for male, female and mixed relay teams.To celebrate  years in business, MB McGrady  Co. will be rewarding runners that finish th, th, th and th with pound sports vouchers.For further information on Jimmyrsquos k visit www.EastDownAC..prettyPhoto

title: Plans to improve Quoile walkway are welcomed
story: PLANS to signicantly enhance walkways along the banks of the Quoile River in Downpatrick have been warmly welcomed.The upgrade is part of an ambitious master plan which has been drawn up for the area by Newry, Mourne and Down Council under its Covid recovery initiative with funding also provided by the Department for Infrastructure.The local authority aims to upgrade large sections of the river walk from the Belfast Road and along Janersquos Shore pathway to connect to the Quoile Pondage area where paths have already been resurfaced.In addition, ageing boardwalks will be replaced alongside fencing, while gates and signs will also be updated. Improved disabled access is also part of the investment plan which will result in a number of paths being widened.Council officials say the planned improvements are essential for local people who are increasingly using the trails as part of their daily routine and commute.Since the start of the Covid pandemic, there has been a major increase in the number of people walking along the banks of the Quoile with this set to increase over the spring and summer.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason and Downpatrick councillors Oonagh Hanlon and Gareth Sharvin are delighted with the master plan and the benefit that it will provide for the town, its residents and visitors.Cllr Mason said due to Covid- restrictions, many areas across the district have experienced an increased use of outdoor spaces.ldquoThis has been so important for the health and wellbeing of residents and visitors to our area, she continued.ldquoThe Quoile in particular has been extremely busy with families and friends using the location for running, walking, cycling or simply meeting up with each other. The need for good quality outdoor space has never been as important.Cllr Hanlon said she was ldquoexcited to see the first phase of the local authorityrsquos Covid recovery scheme being rolled out.ldquoI am pleased the work will include enhancing boardwalks and paths at Jane Shore with improved disability access in particular at the gates which will be of particular interest to local anglers who have lobbied for better access, she said.ldquoThis work is vital in enhancing the tourist and heritage offerings we have locally and create better linkages to the town centre.Cllr Sharvin said the joint local authority and government department investment will signicantly improve access along the Janes Shore area and help disabled anglers in particular who have highlighted with him the challenges they face of accessing the walkway.ldquoThe planned improvements will enable everyone to enjoy the uniqueness of the Quoile area as a recreational and tourism asset, he said.Cllr Sharvin said work to resurface the footpath, replace wooden fencing and walking boards, in tandem with the provision of new accessibility gates and cutting back trees and hedging will make a major dference.He said the foliage will be cut back next month and when that is completed, it is hoped that work on the other planned improvements will get underway.The Quoile Angling Club is holding its annual meeting in Murphyrsquos bar, Downpatrick, on March  at pm..prettyPhoto

title: Preservation order put on hold pending planning application
story: A DECISION to make a preservation order to protect trees at the centre of the Exploris Ropebridge car park project in Portaferry has been put on hold.The Department of Infrastructureconfirmed this week that it will wait for the outcome of a planning application before it decides what to do with the trees that local people are campaigning to save.Ards and North Down Borough Council lodged a planning application with its own planning department last December  to gain permission to build an extended car and coach on its own land near the popular visitor venue.The project has been controversial since local conservationists discovered last year that in order to build the car-park, nine mature protected trees would need to be removed.It was later confirmed that the council did not have the authority to remove the trees under a permitted development and needed to apply for planning permission for the car-park which should have been competed by next month.The Portaferry Stop The Trees campaign gathered more than , names in opposition to the trees cull and even offered the council an alternative design which would have saved the trees but resulted in less parking spaces. The design was rejected by the council.The campaign started last May when contractors turned up with equipment and portacabins and marked the trees for felling.Local resident Lily Devlin noticed the development and started the campaign, first rallying support via her Facebook page, and then starting an online petition.Speaking on behalf of the Save the Trees Campaign group, Cathie McKimm said: ldquoThe council got this wrong from the beginning.ldquoWe now have a situation where the council are applying for planning permission for a project they have already appointed contractors for and the project has increased by almost % in cost.ldquoIn bringing in experts to late at a huge cost to the ratepayer to fix the many mistakes theyrsquove made, including failing to include a drainage system in a flood risk area, the council are now having to contribute more than pound, to this scheme and growing, whereas before they were only contributing approximately pound, for the same scheme. ldquoGiven all the conflicts of interest that the council now have we do not believe they can assess this planning application objectively, and believe that the Department of Infrastructure needs to call it in and conduct a full investigation about how this has been handled.A council spokesman confirmed that a planning application for the project would follow regulations which apply to all councils throughout Northern Ireland in making its decision.He said: ldquoThe council will let matters follow due process, mindful of the procedures put in place by the Department for such planning applications.He also confirmed that the project, which was planned as a local tourism boost, had increased in costs.ldquoThe council has applied for and obtained funding of pound, towards the project. At the start of the regeneration scheme, the proposed costs were circa pound,, he said.ldquoHowever, with the passage of time, increased construction costs and refinement of the scheme , the costs were last estimated at circa pound, which was agreed by council in October .A DfI spokesperson confirmed it had initially considered making a preservation order on the trees.He added: ldquoHowever, on January  , the council confirmed that it had instead opted to submit a planning application. This was lodged on December  to the Planning Service of the council. The necessity of whether it is expedient to complete the process of making a TPO is on hold pending the outcome of the planning application..prettyPhoto

title: Smell wind of change as lambs leap around fields
story: IT is spring again in Lecale and new le abounds in the fields. Daffodils are peaking out of the ground, the weather is softening, and the feast of St Brigidrsquos Day , February , has passed.This can mean only one thing ndash lambs! In fact, lambs have been born in our practice since before Christmas. But the majority will be coming to a field near you over the next few weeks.Now, modern flocks have a lot of sheep in them. Indeed, there are about five million sheep in Ireland overall. Thatrsquos one for every man, woman and child.Our domestic sheepis descended from a primitive European ancestor, today found mainly in Corsica. In the past it was common for sheep to havejust one lamb. But today, thanks to better feeding, shelter and shepherding, it is possible for sheep to have twins, triplets and even quads!This abundance can come with problems though. Whata sheep doesnrsquot have enough milk to feed this many lambs  Well, farmers have come up with a number of solutions.The first is lsquopet lambsrsquo. These lambs are hand reared. They are fed with a bottle using condensed milk from commercial suppliers. Or the milk can be taken from another ewe who is producing a lot.As anyone with a baby will tell you, this solution is labour intensive and will keep the shepherd working around the clock. But they are dedicated, and they do it! It is not always sustainable in the long run. Another solution is fostering.Lamb fostering is where a ewe adopts the lamb from another ewe. The reasons for fostering can be manold. A lack of milk is one of the major reasons. The ewe may not want to take on another lamb, not recognising it as her own, but shepherds have adapted one of naturersquos many wonders to encourage it to happen.They use a technique called olfactory imprinting. Have you ever wondered how a ewe can recognise her own lamb in a flock of hundreds  One reason is that, just after birth, the ewe learns the smell of her newborn. This is what olfactory imprinting means.Shepherds can take advantage of this amazing process by rubbing some of the birthing fluid of the newborn lamb into the wool of the lamb to be fostered. The ewe will then accept the lamb as one of her own, and feed and care for it. The lives of many lambs are saved in this way.So when you next look at the fields of Lecale, check out the sheep and seeyou can tell them apart. Evenyou canrsquot, their mums can!.prettyPhoto

title: Ulster Aviation Society left ‘dismayed’ over council at Festival of Flight decision
story: THE decision by Newry, Mourne and Down Council to cancel this summerrsquos international Festival of Flight in Newcastle was taken without consulting one of its key partners, it has emerged.Last weekrsquos decision to pull the plug on the event mdash which was last held in  mdash was taken in secret during a meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Tourist and Regeneration Committee.It is understood that no contact was made with the Ulster Aviation Society which has played a major role since the inaugural festival and described its disappointment at the cancellation decision.Regularly attracting in the region of , people to the resort in the summer, the flagship tourist event has been a major success for over a decade.Council officials say that due to the challenges in planning such a major festival, securing commitments from participants and with the uncertainty caused to date by the pandemic, organising this yearrsquos event would not be possible.Some councillors believe that given the local authorityrsquos St Patrickrsquos Day parades in Downpatrick and Newry are set to go ahead next month and with the further easing of Covid regulations, some form of airshow could have been organised for Newcastle this summer.This week, Slieve Croob councillor Alan Lewis urging the council to confirm that next yearrsquos festival will go ahead.The Ulster Aviation Society said it was ldquodisappointed and dismayed about the cancellation of the airshow and the fact that the organisation had not been consulted.Society chairman Ray Burrows said it was ldquoastonishing that the event had been ldquoshot down in secret, with no reasonable explanation.Mournes councillor Willie Clarke has urged the local council to ldquograsp the opportunity and organise an alternative event, suggesting a large scale festival that incorporates and builds on the most popular elements of the Festival of Flight.He is keen to see an event showcasing the regionrsquos ldquooutstanding food and drink offering with Newcastle a designated venue for arts, culture and music events to create opportunities showcasing the entrepreneurial spirit and pioneering innovation of the district.Mr Burrows said while these were ldquoall excellent suggestions, he said as elements in addition to, or within, the Festival of Flight, surely not as a replacement for it.He continued: ldquoThat said, we would be pleased indeed to meet with the council or the mayor to discuss the matter. We want to help Newcastle demonstrate in a powerful, popular way how important our aviation future and heritage are to Northern Ireland.ldquoThatrsquos exactly what did in recent years, before Covid.ldquoWe [the UAS] had probably the most popular exhibition within the ground-based event and thousands of parents have brought their children for photographs in our Spitfire and our Alouette helicopter, at no charge.Mr Burrows suggested that unless the councilrsquos decision is reversed, or at least re-assessed, he expects there will be tremendous disappointment from the public.The international festival was cancelled in  because of bad weather and in  and last year because of the Covid- pandemic it was also grounded.Urging the local authority to confirm that it will be chocks away for next summerrsquos Festival of Flight, Cllr Lewis said that for the past two years, the organisation has been unable to deliver a tourism events programme due to the impact of Covid-.ldquoAlthough the possible impact of future Covid iants is dficult to predict, it is hoped that larger scale events can resume this summer. This will be a welcome boost to residents and the local trade and hospitality sectors, he continued.ldquoCouncil research indicates that almost poundm was generated in  for the district as a direct result of tourism events. Therefore, it is bitterly disappointing that this yearrsquos Festival of Flight will not be going ahead.Cllr Lewis said the income that it would have generated would be a welcome boost to traders in the town and benefit the collective tourism industry across South Down.He continued: ldquoWe must not underestimate the huge draw of this annual festival. I note that council officers have said that throughout this past  months they had continued to engage with key stakeholders including the RAF.ldquoIt was advised that due to challenges planning the festival, securing air assets and the uncertainty of the pandemic that it has not been possible to host the festival of flight this year.Cllr Lewis revealed that he has been contacted by many aviation enthusiasts who are bitterly disappointed that the festival wonrsquot go ahead.He added: ldquoI fail to see how the event couldnrsquot have at least been planned for later in the year, now that we know the majority of restrictions are to be lted. I am asking the council to alleviate fears by confirming that the Festival of Flight hasnrsquot be shelved. Every effort must be made to ensure this wonderful attraction be ed to Newcastle which has been its home for  years..prettyPhoto

From then and onwards, our congregations have been meeting for Sunday worship and other weekly meetings. “Since our congregations y in terms of numbers attending and, in building size etc, our general presbytery directed each local church kirk session and committee to plan and manage details of a fullto worship. This was the case after the first pandemic lockdown in .”   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Tyrone’s Ditches Presbyterian Church, Poyntzpass, Co Armagh. Picture: Billy MaxwellMr Greer added: “Therefore, when the health minister lted all remaining restrictions, the presbytery authorised kirk sessions and committees to proceed with removal of remaining mitigations as they see fit at the local level. This will y from congregation to congregation with regard to the timing and details of it.”However, Mr Greer stressed that as a denomination his church is fully aware that the pandemic virus is still within society. “Therefore, we will endeavour to proceed with care in the removal of remaining mitigations. For example, we will also show respect and liberty toward those who wish to continue wearing face coverings, either entering or leaving our buildings or while seated for worship.“Our worship services are open to all – our own members and adherents, and also any from the public at large who wish to visit. We must emphasise our gratitude to the Lord for His mercy in bringing us to this point where church le is more back to full ministry at all levels.”• The Free Presbyterian general presbytery, in a statement this week, said: “We give thanks to God for looking upon the nation in mercy, and withdrawing the more extreme symptoms of the covid pandemic, which caused death and serious illness. “We are grateful for removal of all statutory restrictions upon our public worship and have authorised our sessions and committees to take the necessary steps, transitioning our people back to normality. We continue to pray for all who have been affected by the pandemic through bereavement and illness and that they will know God’s grace and comfort.”——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: this is no time for vote for parties who seek an isolated brexit britain
story: Booing of DUP MP Sammy Wilson at Markethill rally was deserved    motorists ‘engaged in anti-social behaviour’ in NI townNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionThis is no time for vote for political parties who seek an isolated Brexit BritainA letter from Dr Carol Greer:By LettersTuesday, st March , : pm  "       "  Letter to the editorI have been deeply moved by the bravery of the people of Ukraine and their inspiring leader Volodymyr Zelenskyy. This has made me think about what I want in the leader of my country and what values I want my country to promote. I do not expect political leaders to be saints and have only passing disappointment on learning of inappropriate tweets or the fact that a le long politician thinks of jumping ship when his party isn’t working for him anymore. I do have a harder time with politicians who become apologists for Irish people who killed other Irish people in the name of political change but we made a commitment in the Good Friday Agreement to move on from past resentments. But I do want my politicians to promote the ideals I believed were synonymous with being part of these islands….Democracy, compassion and a sense that our neighbours are owed more than rhetoric when war lands on their doorstep.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.A majority of decent people believed, and voted for the separation of the UK from our neighbours via Brexit, feeding on the deep-set feeling of being overlooked that is common in many poorer communities in the UK. Self-interest led politicians promoting Brexit to reject the relationships that made the UK a successful global economy. The DUP got on the Brexit train knowing it could cost the Northern Ireland economy dear. They are now prepared to leave NI open to direct rule by this very Tory government who are failing so abysmally to take on Putin, who are responding to Ukraine’s humanitarian refugee crisis with empty words and red tape they prioritise keeping anti immigration rhetoric in place to appease right wing ERG supporters. So how do I stay proud of my country in the way the Ukrainian people can hold their heads high  We must not become a narrow minded, inward looking country. It is crucial that in May we do not elect in Northern Ireland parties that are only too happy to hand our futures to charlatans or who have tied their future to the success of Boris’s failed vision of an isolated lonely Britain.Dr Carol Greer, Belfast BT——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. Understood to date back to , the B Listed Building has been sympathetically renovated, with listed features restored to their original character, at a cost of approximately £,.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.One of the spacious rooms in the new Royal Black headquartersThe substantial refurbishment, carried out by Weir Bros ConstructionLtd, Aughnacloy, includes a host of modern facilities and amenities which will allow the Royal Black Institution to flourish in the st century.These include new administrative offices, exhibition space, a library to house the institution’s collection of books and artefacts, meeting rooms, reception area, kitchen, toilet block, outdoor memorial area, and car parking facilities.The Loughgall building is the first time the loyal order – founded in  – has ever owned its headquarters.The institution had been an anchor tenant in Brownlow House, Lurgan, since the late s. Prior to being in Lurgan, the organisation’s administrative base was located in Dublin and Belfast.The Royal Black moved out of Brownlow House in  to temporary premises in Loughgall, beside the Museum of Orange Heritage at Sloan’s House.Now, the institution is looking forward to taking up residence in their own purpose-built administrative centre.“The opening of our new headquarters will be a landmark day in the history of the Royal Black Institution,” said Rev Anderson.“This project has been one of the biggest and most important ever undertaken by the Imperial Grand Black Chapter of the British Commonwealth.“The need for our own headquarters was discussed and agreed in , we purchased the Loughgall building in , renovation work began in May , and I’m delighted to say we’re ready to cut the ribbon on Saturday, April .“It has been a long road to get to this point, and there have been many challenges along the way. “We had originally hoped to open the building in , so that the unveiling would form part of our celebrations for the centenary of Northern Ireland. However, the Covid pandemic wreaked havoc with our work schedule. But we were fairly relaxed about the delay as our focus was always about completing the building to a high standard rather than rushing to a completion date.“There are so many people to thank for all their hard work but I would like to take this opportunity to pay special tribute to the contractors, Weir Bros Construction, for their professionalism and attention to detail, and to our own clerk of works, Edgar Patterson, and quantity surveyor, Keith Anderson, and the entire Royal Black HQ project team, for their passion, commitment and expertise over the last few years.“Thanks to the efforts of everyone involved, we now have modern headquarters from which we can proudly maintain our stand for the Reformed Faith and strengthen our Christian and charitable outreach.”The building itself has an interesting history. At one stage it was a public house known as the Rock Tavern. Afterwards, a temperance advocate, Cecilia Cope, turned it into a coffee house. A later inhabitant was Field Marshal Sir Gerald Templer, a senior British Army officer and former chief of the Imperial General Staff, who fought in both world wars. In more recent times it housed a popular antiques business.The grand opening will also include the opening of a ‘Leaders’ Legacy’ exhibition on the lives of past sovereign grand masters, and the unveiling and dedication of a bust of Sir Norman Stronge. Sir Norman Stronge was a former sovereign grand master who led the institution from  to .A hero of the Somme and a senior Ulster Unionist politician, having served for  years as speaker of the House of Commons of Northern Ireland, he was murdered in January  when an IRA gang burst into his home, Tynan Abbey in Co Armagh, and shot dead the -year-old, together with his only son, James, also a
